sourceString: Preliminary Estimates of the Prevalence of Selected Underlying Health Conditions Among Patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 — United States, February 12–March 28, 2020
targetString: Ebiteeberezebwa Ebisookerwako ku Birondeddwa mu Mbeera z’Abalwadde abalina obulwadde bwa Coronavirus 2019 — United States, Ogwokubiri 12–Ogwokusatu 28, 2020

sourceString: On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) a pandemic.
targetString: Nga 11 Ogwokusatu, 2020, Ekitongole ky’Ensi yonna eky’Ebyobulamu (WHO) kyalangirira obulwadde bwa Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) ng’ekizibu eky’awamu mu nsi.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, a total of 571,678 confirmed COVID-19 cases and 26,494 deaths have been reported worldwide.
targetString: Nga 28 Ogwokusatu 2020 we lwatuukira, omugatte gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 gwali 571,678 n’abafudde nga bali 26,494 mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: Reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe disease include older age and the presence of at least one of several underlying health conditions.
targetString: Ebiva mu China ne Italy biraga nti ensonga ez’obulabe ku bulwadde buno zizingiramu okukulirira mu myaka n’okusangibwamu waakiri obulwadde obw’engeri emu.

sourceString: U.S. older adults, including those aged ≥65 years and particularly those aged ≥85 years, also appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated outcomes; however, data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.
targetString: Abantu abakulu mu U.S. omuli n’abo abalina emyaka ≥65, ate naddala abo abalina emyaka ≥85 nabo balabika bali mu bulabe bwa maanyi obw’okulumbibwa ekirwadde kya COVID-19; wabula, obubaka obunnyonnyola obulwadde abalwadde ba COVID-19 bwe balina tebunnaba kutegeezebwa.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data on underlying health conditions and other known risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections were reported.
targetString: Nga 28 Ogwokusatu, 2020 we lwatuukira, amasaza ga U.S. gaategeeza nti waliwo abalwadde ba COVID-19 abawera 122,653 mu U.S. ku CDC omwo nga mwe muli 7,162 (5.8%) abaggyibwako obubaka obukwata ku ndwadde endala n’obulabe obulala bwe balina mu muyungiro gw’okussa.

sourceString: Among these 7,162 cases, 2,692 (37.6%) patients had one or more underlying health condition or risk factor, and 4,470 (62.4%) had none of these conditions reported.
targetString: Mu balwadde bano 7,162, abalwadde 2,692 (37.6%) baalina obuzibu obw’engeri emu bwe baasangibwa nabwo oba obulabe obulala, ate ng’abalwadde 4,470 (62.4%) bo tebaalina mbeera za ngeri eyo zaategeezebwa.

sourceString: The percentage of COVID-19 patients with at least one underlying health condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1,037, 71%) than that among those who were not hospitalized (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).
targetString: Omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 ku kikumi abalina waakiri embeera y’obulwadde obulala oba obulabe obulala gwali munene mu balwadde abaali beetaaga okussibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi (ICU) (358 of 457, 78%) n’abo abaali beetaaga okuweebwa ebitanda naye nga tebateekeddwa ku bujjanjabi bwa maanyi (732 of 1,037, 71%) okusinga abo abaali tebeetaaga kuweebwa bitanda mu malwaliro (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).

sourceString: The most commonly reported conditions were diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease.
targetString: Obulwadde obwasinga okulabibwa mwalimu sukaali (diabetes mellitus), obulwadde bw’amawuggwe obw’olukonvuba n’obulwadde bw’omutima (cardiovascular disease).

sourceString: These preliminary findings suggest that in the United States, persons with underlying health conditions or other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections appear to be at a higher risk for severe disease from COVID-19 than are persons without these conditions.
targetString: Ebizuuliddwa bino ebisookerwako biraga nti mu Amerika, abantu abasangibwa n’obulwadde oba obuzibu obulala obw’obulabe obukosa omuyungiro gw’okussa balabika okubeera mu bulabe bwa maanyi obw’okukosebwa COVID-19 okusinga abantu abatalina buzibu bulinga obwo.

sourceString: Data from laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases reported to CDC from 50 states, four U.S. territories and affiliated islands, the District of Columbia, and New York City with February 12–March 28, 2020 onset dates were analyzed.
targetString: Obubaka obuva mu ggezeserezo bwakakasa abalwadde ba COVID-19 obwategeezebwa CDC okuva mu mawanga 50, ebitundu bya U.S. bina wamu n’ebizinga ebikolagana n’amawanga ago, District of Columbia, ne New York City nga 12 Ogwokubiri – 28 Ogwokusatu, 2020 ng’ennaku z’omwezi ezitandikirwako.

sourceString: Cases among persons repatriated to the United States from Wuhan, China, and the Diamond Princess cruise ship were excluded.
targetString: Abalwadde abaali mu bantu abazzibwa mu United States okuva mu Wuhan, China, ne Diamond Princess cruise ship tebaabalibwa.

sourceString: For cases with missing onset dates, date of onset was estimated by subtracting 4 days (median interval from symptom onset to specimen collection date among cases with known dates in these data) from the earliest specimen collection.
targetString: Ku balwadde abataliiko nnaku za mwezi zitandikirwako, ennaku z’omwezi ezitandikirwako zaateeberezebwa na kwawula nnaku 4 (omuwendo omukkati okuva obubonero lwe bwatandika okulabika n’ennaku z’omwezi ezimanyiddwa lwe baggyibwako sampolo mu balwadde abamnyiddwako ennaku z’omwezi ku bubaka bwabwe) okuva ku sampolo ezaasooka okukuŋŋaanyizibwa.

sourceString: Public health departments reported cases to CDC using a standardized case report form that captures information (yes, no, or unknown) on the following conditions and potential risk factors: chronic lung disease (inclusive of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], and emphysema); diabetes mellitus; cardiovascular disease; chronic renal disease; chronic liver disease; immunocompromised condition; neurologic disorder, neurodevelopmental, or intellectual disability; pregnancy; current smoking status; former smoking status; or other chronic disease.
targetString: Ebitongole by’Ebyobulamu byategeeza CDC nti waaliwo abalwadde nga bikozesa alipoota eyali etegekeddwa okuva mu bubaka obwakuŋŋaanyizibwanga (yee, nedda, tekimanyiddwa) ku mbeera zino wammanga n’ensonga eziyinza okuba ez’obulabe: obulwadde bw’amawuggwe obw’olukonvuba (omwo nga mwe muli olufuba, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], ne emphysema); sukaali (diabetes mellitus); obulwadde bw’omutima (cardiovascula disease); obulwadde bw’ensigo obw’olukonvuba (chronic renal disease); obulwadde bw’ekibumba obw’olukonvuba (chronic liver disease); obusibage obutakola (immunocompromised condition); obuzibu ku muyungiro gw’obusimu (neurologic disorder), obulemu ku busimu (neurodevelopmental disability), oba obulemu ku bwongo (intellectual disability); abalina embuto; okunywa oba obutanywa sigala mu kiseera kino; eyali anyweddeko oba atanywangako ku sigala oba endwadde endala ez’olukonvuba.

sourceString: Data reported to CDC are preliminary and can be updated by health departments over time; critical data elements might be missing at the time of initial report; thus, this analysis is descriptive, and no statistical comparisons could be made.
targetString: Obubaka obuweerezebwa CDC bwa kiseera era busobola okutereezebwa ebitongole by’ebyobulamu nga wayise ekiseera; wayinza okubaawo ebibula mu bubaka obwo mu kiseera we busooka okuweerezebwa; noolwekyo okwekenneenya kuno kunnyonnyozi era tewali bibalo byandiyinzizza kukolebwa.

sourceString: The percentages of patients of all ages with underlying health conditions who were not hospitalized, hospitalized without ICU admission, and hospitalized with ICU admission were calculated.
targetString: Emiwendo ku kikumi egy’abalwadde ab’emyaka gyonna abalina obulwadde bwe baasangibwa nabwo abataaweebwa bitanda, abaaweebwa ebitanda ne bataweebwa bujjanjabi bwa maanyi, n’abaaweebwa ebitanda ne baweebwa objjanjabi obw’amaanyi gyabalibwa.

sourceString: Percentages of hospitalizations with and without ICU admission were estimated for persons aged ≥19 years with and without underlying health conditions.
targetString: Emiwendo ku kikumi egy’abalwadde abaaweebwa ebitanda mu malwaliro ne bassibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi n’obutali bwa maanyi bwateeberezebwa okuba mu bantu abalina emyaka ≥19 abaasangibwa n’abataasangibwa na bulwadde bulala.

sourceString: This part of the analysis was limited to persons aged ≥19 years because of the small sample size of cases in children with reported underlying health conditions (N = 32).
targetString: Ekitundu ky’okwekaliriza kino kyakugirwa ku bantu abalina emyaka ≥19 olw’omuwendo gw’abaana omutono ogugeraageranyizibwako abaategeezebwa nga baasangibwamu endwadde endala (N = 32).

sourceString: To account for missing data among these preliminary reports, ranges were estimated with a lower bound including cases with both known and unknown status for hospitalization with and without ICU admission as the denominator and an upper bound using only cases with known outcome status as the denominator.
targetString: Okusobola okufaayo ku bubaka obubulako mu alipoota ez’ekiseera, emiwendo egy’ebigero gyateeberezebwa n’egya wansi omwo nga mwe muli n’abalwadde abamanyiddwa n’abatamanyiddwa oba baafuna ebitanda mu malwaliro ne bafuna oba ne batafuna bujjanjabi bwa najwulo nga kye kikozesebwa ng’ekisalirwako ate era n’okusalira ku balwadde abamanyiddwako embeera y’obulamu bwabwe nga bamaze okukeberebwa.

sourceString: Because of small sample size and missing data on underlying health conditions among COVID-19 patients who died, case-fatality rates for persons with and without underlying conditions were not estimated.
targetString: Olw’omuwendo omutono ogugeraageranyizibwako n’obubaka obutaliiwo ku bulwadde abalwadde ba COVID-19 bwe baasangibwa nabwo naye ng’abalwadde abo baafa, emiwendo gy’abalwadde abaafa nga balina oba nga tebalina bulwadde bulala tegyateeberezebwa.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, a total of 122,653 laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases (Figure) and 2,112 deaths were reported to CDC.
targetString: Nga 28 Ogwokusatu 2020, omugatte gw’abalwadde 122,653 abaakeberebwa mu ggezeserezo ne bakakasibwa nti balina COVID-19 (Ekifaananyi) n’abaafa 2,112 be baaweerezebwa ku CDC.

sourceString: Case report forms were submitted to CDC for 74,439 (60.7%) cases.
targetString: Foomu z’abalwadde 74,439 (60.7%) enzijuze zaaweerezebwa ku CDC.

sourceString: Data on presence or absence of underlying health conditions and other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections (i.e., smoking and pregnancy) were available for 7,162 (5.8%) patients (Table 1).
targetString: Obubaka ku baasangibwa n’obulwadde oba abataasangibwa nabwo n’obuzibu obulala obw’obulabe ku muyungiro gw’okussa (kwe kugamba, okunywa sigala n’okubeera n’olubuto) bwaliwo era nga bwa balwadde 7,162 (5.8%) (Omweso 1).

sourceString: Approximately one third of these patients (2,692, 37.6%), had at least one underlying condition or risk factor.
targetString: Mu kuteebereza, abalwadde ebitundu nga kimu kyakusatu (2,692, 37.6%), baasangibwa n’obulwadde oba n’obuzibu obw’obulabe.

sourceString: Diabetes mellitus (784, 10.9%), chronic lung disease (656, 9.2%), and cardiovascular disease (647, 9.0%) were the most frequently reported conditions among all cases.
targetString: Sukaali (diabetes mellitus) (784, 10.9%), obulwadde bw’ekibumba obw’olukonvuba (656, 9.2%), n’obulwadde bw’omutima (647, 9.0%) bwe bulwadde obwasinga okulabika mu balwadde bonna.

sourceString: Among 457 ICU admissions and 1,037 non-ICU hospitalizations, 358 (78%) and 732 (71%), respectively occurred among persons with one or more reported underlying health condition.
targetString: Mu balwadde 457 abaaweebwa ebitanda ne bassibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi n’abalwadde 1,037 abaaweebwa ebitanda naye ne batassibwa ku bujjanjabi bwa maanyi, 358 (78%) ne 732 (71%), ng’emiwendo bwe gigoberegana be baazuulibwa mu balwadde abaasangibwa n’obulwadde obw’engeri emu oba okusingawo.

sourceString: In contrast, 1,388 of 5,143 (27%) COVID-19 patients who were not hospitalized were reported to have at least one underlying health condition.
targetString: Mu kugeraageranya, abalwadde 1,388 ku 5,143 (27%) abalina COVID-19 abataaweebwa bitanda mu ddwaliro baategeeza nti baasangibwa waakiri n’obulwadde obw’engeri emu.

sourceString: Among patients aged ≥19 years, the percentage of non-ICU hospitalizations was higher among those with underlying health conditions (27.3%–29.8%) than among those without underlying health conditions (7.2%–7.8%); the percentage of cases that resulted in an ICU admission was also higher for those with underlying health conditions (13.3%–14.5%) than those without these conditions (2.2%–2.4%) (Table 2).
targetString: Mu balwadde abaalina emyaka ≥19, omuwendo ku kikumi ogw’abalwadde abaaweebwa ebitanda naye ne batassibwa ku bujjanjabi bwa maanyi gwali munene ku abo abaasangibwa n’obulwadde obulala (27.3%–29.8%) okusinga abo abataasangibwa na bulwadde bulala (7.2%–7.8%); omuwendo gw’abalwadde ku kimu abaaweebwa ebitanda ne bassibwa ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi nagwo gwali waggulu mu balwadde abaasangibwa n’obulwadde obulala (13.3%–14.5%) okusinga abo abataasangibwa na bulwadde bulala (2.2%–2.4%) (Omweso 2).

sourceString: Small numbers of COVID-19 patients aged < 19 years were reported to be hospitalized (48) or admitted to an ICU (eight).
targetString: Omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba COVID-19 mutono abaalina emyaka egikka wansi wa 19 kyategeerekeka nti baaweebwa ebitanda (48) oba baaweebwa obujjanjabi obw’amaanyi (munaana).

sourceString: In contrast, 335 patients aged < 19 years were not hospitalized and 1,342 had missing data on hospitalization.
targetString: Mu kugeraageranya, abalwadde 335 abaalina emyaka egikka wansi wa 19 tebaaweebwa bitanda ate 1,342 tebaalina biboogerako kulaga oba nga baaweewa ebitanda.

sourceString: Among all COVID-19 patients with complete information on underlying conditions or risk factors, 184 deaths occurred (all among patients aged ≥19 years); 173 deaths (94%) were reported among patients with at least one underlying condition.
targetString: Mu balwadde ba COVID-19 abaalina obubaka obujjuvu ku bulwadde obulala bwe baasangibwa nabwo, abalwadde 184 baafa (bonna baali mu balwadde ab’emyaka ≥19); abaafa 173 (94%) kyategeezebwa nti baali mu balwadde abaasangibwa waakiri n’obulwadde obulala.

sourceString: Among 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases reported to CDC as of March 28, 2020, 7,162 (5.8%) patients had data available pertaining to underlying health conditions or potential risk factors; among these patients, higher percentages of patients with underlying conditions were admitted to the hospital and to an ICU than patients without reported underlying conditions.
targetString: Mu balwadde 122,653 mu U.S. aba COVID-19 abaaweerezebwa ku CDC nga 28 Ogwokusatu 2020, abalwadde 7,162 (5.8%) baalina obubaka obubakwatako ku ndwadde endala ze baasangibwa nazo oba obulabe obulala; mu balwadde abo, omuwendo ku kikumi munene ku abo abaasangibwa n’obulwadde obulala baaweebwa ebitanda era ne bassibwa ne ku bujjanjabi obw’amaanyi okusinga abalwadde abataasangibwa na bulwadde bulala.

sourceString: These results are consistent with findings from China and Italy, which suggest that patients with underlying health conditions and risk factors, including, but not limited to, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, COPD, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, chronic renal disease, and smoking, might be at higher risk for severe disease or death from COVID-19.
targetString: Ebyazuulibwa bino bikwatagana n’ebyazuulibwa mu China ne Italy, ekitegeeza nti abalwadde abaalina endwadde endala n’obulabe obulala ng’obumu ku bwo mulimu sukaali (diabetes mellitus), puleesa (hypertension), COPD, obulwadde bw’omusiwa ogutwala omusaayi ku mutima, obulwadde bw’obwongo (cerebrovascular disease), chronic renal disease, n’okunywa sigala, bayinza okuba n’emikisa gy’okulwala ennyo oba okuttibwa COVID-19.

sourceString: This analysis was limited by small numbers and missing data because of the burden placed on reporting health departments with rapidly rising case counts, and these findings might change as additional data become available.
targetString: Okwekaliriza kuno kwakomerwa emiwendo emitono n’obubaka obutaaliwo olw’okukaluubirirwa ebitongole by’ebyobulamu kwe byasanga mu kutegeeza obubaka obwo olw’obungi bw’abalwadde abeeyiwa mu malwaliro, era ebyazuulibwa bino biyinza okukyusa obubaka obulala bwe bunaafunika.

sourceString: It is not yet known whether the severity or level of control of underlying health conditions affects the risk for severe disease associated with COVID-19.
targetString: Tekinnaba kutegeerekeka oba ng’obuzibu bw’obulwadde obulala omuntu bw’aba nabwo oba okujjanjaba obulwadde obulala omuntu bwasangiddwa nabwo kikosa obulabe bw’obulwadde obw’amaanyi omuntu bwe yandifunye nga buva ku COVID-19.

sourceString: Many of these underlying health conditions are common in the United States: based on self-reported 2018 data, the prevalence of diagnosed diabetes among U.S. adults was 10.1%, and the U.S. age-adjusted prevalence of all types of heart disease (excluding hypertension without other heart disease) was 10.6% in 2017.
targetString: Obulwadde obwo obulala bwa mwero nnyo mu United States: okusinziira ku bubaka abantu bennyini bwe beewaako mu 2018, omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba sukaali abaasangibwa mu bantu abakulu mu U.S. baali ebitundu 10.1%, ate omuwendo ogwakyusibwamu mu U.S. ogw’abalwadde abalina obulwadde bw’omutima obw’engeri zonna (ng’oggyeeko puleesa omutali ndwadde za mutima ndala) gwali 10.6% mu 2017.

sourceString: The age-adjusted prevalence of COPD among U.S. adults is 5.9%, and in 2018, the U.S. estimated prevalence of current asthma among persons of all ages was 7.9%.
targetString: Emyaka bwe gyakyusibwamu obulwadde bwa COPD mu bantu abakulu mu U.S. ne gidda ku 5.9%, ate mu 2018, U.S. yateebereza nti obulwadde bw’olufuba obwali mu bantu ab’emyaka gyonna bwali ku 7.9%.

sourceString: CDC continues to develop and update resources for persons with underlying health conditions to reduce the risk of acquiring COVID-19.
targetString: CDC kigenda mu maaso n’okukulaakulanya n’okuzza obuggya ebikozesebwa abantu abalina obulwadde obulala okusobola okukendeeza ku bulabe bw’okukwatibwa COVID-19.

sourceString: The estimated higher prevalence of these conditions among those in this early group of U.S. COVID-19 patients and the potentially higher risk for more severe disease from COVID-19 associated with the presence of underlying conditions highlight the importance of COVID-19 prevention in persons with underlying conditions.
targetString: Omuwendo oguteeberezebwa ogw’embeera ezo mu abo abali mu kibinja kino ekyasooka eky’abalwadde ba COVID-19 mu U.S. abalwadde ba COVID-19 wamu n’obulabe obw’amaani obw’obulwadde obw’obulabe obuva ku COVID-19 obwekwanya n’obulwadde obulala bwe baalina bulaga bulungi omugaso gw’okutangira COVID-19 mu bantu abalina obulwadde obulala.

sourceString: The findings in this report are subject to at least six limitations.
targetString: Ebizuuliddwa ebiri mu alipoota eno bikugirwa waakiri ebintu mukaaga.

sourceString: First, these data are preliminary, and the analysis was limited by missing data related to the health department reporting burden associated with rapidly rising case counts and delays in completion of information requiring medical chart review; these findings might change as additional data become available.
targetString: Ekisooka, obubaka buno bwe busookerwako era okwekaliriza kwakugirwa obubaka obwekwanya ku kitongole ky’ebyobulamu ekyategeeza obuzito bw’okufuna abalwadde abangi wamu n’okulwawo okujjuza obubaka obwali bwetaagisa okwekaliriza ekipande ky’omulwadde; ebyazuulibwa bino bisobola okukyuka obubaka obulala bwe bunaafunika.

sourceString: Information on underlying conditions was only available for 7,162 (5.8%) of 122,653 cases reported to CDC.
targetString: Obubaka obukwata ku ndwadde endala abantu ze balina bwaliwo ku balwadde 7,162 (5.8%) ku 122,653 abaaweerezebwa ku CDC.

sourceString: It cannot be assumed that those with missing information are similar to those with data on either hospitalizations or underlying health conditions.
targetString: Tekisobola kutwalibwa butwalibwa nti abo abataliiko bubaka obwo be bamu n’abo abalina obubaka ku kuweebwa ebitanda oba abaasangibwa n’endwadde endala.

sourceString: Second, these data are subject to bias in outcome ascertainment because of short follow-up time.
targetString: Ekyokubiri, obubaka buno bwandibaamu kyekubiira ku bivaamu olw’obudde bw’okulondoola okubeera obumpi.

sourceString: Some outcomes might be underestimated, and long-term outcomes cannot be assessed in this analysis.
targetString: Ebivaamu ebirala biyinza obutateeberezebwa bulungi ate ebivaamu eby’ebbanga eggwanvu tebisobola kwekalirizibwa mu kwekenneenya kuno.

sourceString: Third, because of the limited availability of testing in many jurisdictions during this period, this analysis is likely biased toward more severe cases, and findings might change as testing becomes more widespread.
targetString: Ekyokusatu, olw’obufunda bw’okukebera mu bifo ebimu mu kiseera kino, okwekenneenya kuno kulabika okubeeramu kyekubiira ku balwadde abali obubi ennyo era ebizuuliddwa bino bisobola okukyuka obubaka obulala bwe bunaafunika.

sourceString: Fourth, because of the descriptive nature of these data, attack rates among persons with and without underlying health conditions could not be compared, and thus the risk difference of severe disease with COVID-19 between these groups could not be estimated.
targetString: Ekyokuna, olw’okuba obubaka buno bunnyonnyozi okulwala kw’abantu abaalina n’abataalina bulwadde kusobola okugeraageranyizibwa era bwe kityo enjawulo mu bulabe bw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 wakati w’ebibinja bino busobola okuteebereebwa.

sourceString: Fifth, no conclusions could be drawn about underlying conditions that were not included in the case report form or about different conditions that were reported in a single, umbrella category.
targetString: Ekyokutaanu, tewali kukubira kuyinza kutuukibwako ku bulwadde abantu bwe baasangibwa nabwo obutaateekebwa ku foomu y’alipoota z’abwalwadde oba ku mbeera ez’enjawulo ezaategeezebwa ku kibinja ky’abalwadde ab’ekika ekimu.

sourceString: For example, asthma and COPD were included in a chronic lung disease category.
targetString: Okugeza, olufuba ne COPD bwateekebwa mu kibinja ky’obulwadde bw’amawuggwe obw’olukonvuba.

sourceString: Finally, for some underlying health conditions and risk factors, including neurologic disorders, chronic liver disease, being a current smoker, and pregnancy, few severe outcomes were reported; therefore, conclusions cannot be drawn about the risk for severe COVID-19 among persons in these groups.
targetString: Ekisembayo, ku bulwadde obulala abantu bwe baali nabwo n’obulabe obulala omwo nga mwe muli n’obulemu ku bwongo, obulwadde bw’ekibumba obw’olukonvuba, okubeera ng’onywa sigala mu kiseera kino n’okubeera n’olubuto, ebivaamu bitono ebyategeezebwa; awo nno, tewali kukubira kuyinza kutuukibwako ku bulabe bwa COVID-19 mu bantu abagwa mu bibinja bino.

sourceString: Persons in the United States with underlying health conditions appear to be at higher risk for more severe COVID-19, consistent with findings from other countries.
targetString: Abantu b’omu United States abalina obulwadde obulala balabika okuba n’obulabe bwa maanyi okukosebwa ennyo COVID-19, era nga kino kifaanagana n’ebyazuulibwa mu mawanga amalala.

sourceString: Persons with underlying health conditions who have symptoms of COVID-19, including fever, cough, or shortness of breath, should immediately contact their health care provider.
targetString: Abantu abalina obulwadde obulala era nga balina obubonero bwa COVID-19, omuli olusujja, okukolola, oba okukaluubirirwa mu kussa, balina okutuukirira abasawo baabwe amangu ddala.

sourceString: These persons should take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19, through washing their hands; cleaning and disinfecting high-touch surfaces; and social distancing, including staying at home, avoiding crowds, gatherings, and travel, and avoiding contact with persons who are ill.
targetString: Abantu bano balina okubaako bye bakola okwetangira COVID-19, nga banaaba engalo; okulongoosa n’okutta obuwuka kungulu kw’ebintu; n’okwewa amabanga, omwo nga mwe muli okubeera ewaka, okwewala ebifo ebirimu abantu abangi, enkuŋŋaana, n’okutambula, n’okwewala okukwatagana n’abantu abalwadde.

sourceString: Maintaining at least a 30-day supply of medication, a 2-week supply of food and other necessities, and knowledge of COVID-19 symptoms are recommended for those with underlying health conditions.
targetString: Okubeera n’eddagala lya nnaku waakiri 30, okugula emmere ya wiiki 2 n’ebyetaagisa ebirala n’okumanya obubonero bwa COVID-19 bisembebwa okufiibwako eri abantu abalina obulwadde obulala.

sourceString: All persons should take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19 and to protect others.
targetString: Abantu bonna balina okubaako bye bakola okwekuuma COVID-19 ate n’okukuuma abalala.

sourceString: All persons who are ill should stay home, except to get medical care; should not go to work; and should stay away from others.
targetString: Abantu bonna abalwadde balina okusigala ewaka, okuggyako nga bagenda kufuna ddagala; tebalina kugenda kukola; era balina okwewala okusemberera abantu abalala.

sourceString: This is especially important for those who work with persons with underlying conditions or who otherwise are at high risk for severe outcomes from COVID-19.
targetString: Okusingira ddala, kino kikulu eri abo abakola n’abantu abalina obulwadde obulala oba abo abali mu bulabe obw’amaanyi obw’okukosebwa ennyo COVID-19.

sourceString: Community mitigation strategies, which aim to slow the spread of COVID-19, are important to protect all persons from COVID-19, especially persons with underlying health conditions and other persons at risk for severe COVID-19–associated disease (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf).
targetString: Obukodyo bw’ekitundu obukugira, obuyamba okukendeeza ku kusaasaana kwa COVID-19, bukulu mu kutangira abantu obutakwatibwa COVID-19, naddala abantu abalina endwadde endala n’abo abali mu buzibu bw’okulumbibwa endwadde endala ezeekuusa ku COVID-19 (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf).

sourceString: What is already known about this topic?
targetString: Kiki ekimanyiddwa ku nsonga eno?

sourceString: Published reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe COVID-19 disease include underlying health conditions, but data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.
targetString: Alipoota ezifulumiziddwa okuva mu China ne Italy ziraga nti ensonga ez’obulabe ku COVID-19 ow’amaanyi mulimu endwadde endala naye obubaka obunnyonnyola endwadde endala mu balwadde ba U.S. abalina COVID-19 bwe balina tebunnaba kutegeezebwa.

sourceString: What is added by this report?
targetString: Kipya ki ekiri mu alipoota eno?

sourceString: Based on preliminary U.S. data, persons with underlying health conditions such as diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease, appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated disease than persons without these conditions.
targetString: Okusinziira ku bubaka obusookerwako mu U.S., abantu abalina obulwadde obulala gamba nga sukaali, obulwadde bw’amawuggwe obw’olukonvuba (chronic lung disease), n’obulwadde bw’omutima, balabika okubeera mu bulabe bw’endwadde ezeekuusa ku COVID-19 ez’amaanyi okusinga abo abatalina bulwadde bwa ngeri eyo.

sourceString: What are the implications for public health practice?
targetString: Bino bitegeeza ki eri ebyobulamu mu mbeera z’abantu?

sourceString: Strategies to protect all persons and especially those with underlying health conditions, including social distancing and handwashing, should be implemented by all communities and all persons to help slow the spread of COVID-19.
targetString: Obukodyo bw’okukuuma abantu bonna naddala abo abalina endwadde endala, omwo nga mwe muli n’okwesuula amabanga n’okunaaba mu ngalo, bulina okukolebwako abantu bonna mu bitundu byabwe wamu n’abantu bonna kiyambeko mu kukendeeza ku nsaasaana ya COVID-19.

sourceString: Emergence of a Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19): Protocol for Extending Surveillance Used by the Royal College of General Practitioners Research and Surveillance Centre and Public Health England
targetString: Okubalukawo kw’Akawuka ka Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19): Enseetuka y’Okwongezaayo Okulondoola okukolebwa Royal College of General Practitioners Research and Surveillance Centre and Public Health England

sourceString: The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) and Public Health England (PHE) have successfully worked together on the surveillance of influenza and other infectious diseases for over 50 years, including three previous pandemics.
targetString: Ekitongole kya The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) ne Public Health England (PHE) bikoze bulungi mu kulondoola yegu (influenza) n’obulwadde obulala obusiigibwa okumala emyaka 50, omwo nga mwe muli ne nawookeera wa mirundi esatu mu bbanga eriyise.

sourceString: With the emergence of the international outbreak of the coronavirus infection (COVID-19), a UK national approach to containment has been established to test people suspected of exposure to COVID-19.
targetString: Nawookeera wa coronavirus (COVID-19) bwe yabulakawo mu nsi yonna, enteekateeka y’okumulwanyisa yakolebwa mu UK okukebera abantu abateeberezebwa okubeera ne COVID-19.

sourceString: At the same time and separately, the RCGP RSC’s surveillance has been extended to monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community as well as assess the effectiveness of the containment strategy.
targetString: Mu kiseera kyekimu ate mu ngeri ey’enjawulo, okulondoola kwa RCGP RSC kwongezeddwayo okulondoola eby’omunda n’eby’omu bitundu ebirala ebikwata ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 wamu n’okwekaliriza enkola y’obukodyo obukozesebwa okulwanyisa obulwadde buno.

sourceString: The aims of this study are to surveil COVID-19 in both asymptomatic populations and ambulatory cases with respiratory infections, ascertain both the rate and pattern of COVID-19 spread, and assess the effectiveness of the containment policy.
targetString: Ekiruubirirwa ky’okunoonyereza kuno kwe kulondoola COVID-19 mu bantu abeeyolekerako obubonero n’abo abalondoolwa obulondoolwa abalina obuzibu mu kussa, okukenga omuwendo n’ensaasaana ya COVID-19 wamu n’okwekaliriza enkola y’obukodyo bw’okutangira ekirwadde kino.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC, a network of over 500 general practices in England, extract pseudonymized data weekly.
targetString: Ekitongole kya RCGP RSC, omuli abakola ku byobulamu abasukka mu 500 mu Bungereza bafuna obubaka obukwekeze buli wiiki.

sourceString: This extended surveillance comprises of five components: (1) Recording in medical records of anyone suspected to have or who has been exposed to COVID-19.
targetString: Okulondoola kuno okwongezeddwayo kulimu ebintu bitaanu: (1) Okuwandiika mu biwandiiko by’ekisawo eby’omuntu yenna ateeberezebwa okubeera oba alina COVID-19.

sourceString: Computerized medical records suppliers have within a week of request created new codes to support this.
targetString: Ebiwandiiko by’ekisawo eby’oku kompyuta abaweereza bye babeera nabyo mu wiiki emu mwe babisabidde kyaleetawo enkola empya okuwagira kino.

sourceString: (2) Extension of current virological surveillance and testing people with influenza-like illness or lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI)—with the caveat that people suspected to have or who have been exposed to COVID-19 should be referred to the national containment pathway and not seen in primary care.
targetString: (2) Okugaziya okulondoola kw’okunoonyereza n’okukebera abantu abalina yegu (influenza) oba obulwadde bw’omuyungiro gw’okussa ogwa wansi (lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI))—nga waliwo akakwakkulizo nti abantu abateeberezebwa oba abalina COVID-19 balina okuweerezebwa bakolebweko ng’enteekateeka z’eggwanga bwe ziri so si kukolebwako mu malwaliro agasookerwako.

sourceString: (3) Serology sample collection across all age groups.
targetString: (3) Okufuna sampolo z’oluzzizzi mu bantu ab’emyaka gyonna.

sourceString: This will be an extra blood sample taken from people who are attending their general practice for a scheduled blood test.
targetString: Wajja kubaawo sampolo y’omusaayi endala eneggyibwa ku bantu abakola emirimu gyabwe egy’ekisawo egya bulijjo era ng’omusaayi ogwo gwa kukebera okuteeketeeke.

sourceString: The 100 general practices currently undertaking annual influenza virology surveillance will be involved in the extended virological and serological surveillance.
targetString: Abakola ku byobulamu eby’awamu 100 abakola ku kulondoola obuwuka bwa yegu okwa buli mwaka bajja kwetaba mu kulondoola okwongezebwayo okwekenneenya obuwuka ne sampolo (virological and serological surveillance).

sourceString: (4) Collecting convalescent serum samples.
targetString: (4) Okukuŋŋaanya sampolo ku abo abawonye obulwadde (convalescent serum samples).

sourceString: We have the opportunity to escalate the data extraction to twice weekly if needed.
targetString: Tulina omukisa okugaziya enkuŋŋaanya y’obubaka okudda ku mirundi ebiri buli wiiki bwe kiba nga kyetaagisa.

sourceString: Swabs and sera will be analyzed in PHE reference laboratories.
targetString: Obugoye obuyisibwa mu kamwa n’oluzzizzi bijja kwekalirizibwa mu magazeserezo ga PHE.

sourceString: General practice clinical system providers have introduced an emergency new set of clinical codes to support COVID-19 surveillance.
targetString: Abakola ku byekisawo eby’awamu bataddewo enkola ez’amangu empya okuyamba mu kuwagira okulondoola kwa COVID-19.

sourceString: Additionally, practices participating in current virology surveillance are now taking samples for COVID-19 surveillance from low-risk patients presenting with LRTIs.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, abakola ku kulondoola okwekenneenya obuwuka kati bakuŋŋaanya sampolo za kulondoola COVID-19 okuva ku balwadde abataliiko bulabe bwa maanyi abalina LRTIs.

sourceString: Within the first 2 weeks of setup of this surveillance, we have identified 3 cases: 1 through the new coding system, the other 2 through the extended virology sampling.
targetString: Mu wiiki ezaasooka 2 ez’okuteekawo okulondoola kuno tufunyeeyo abalwadde 3: 1 ng’avudde mu nkola empya, ate abalala 2 okuva mu kwongezaayo okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’okwekenneenya obuwuka.

sourceString: We have rapidly converted the established national RCGP RSC influenza surveillance system into one that can test the effectiveness of the COVID-19 containment policy.
targetString: Tukyusizza mu bwangu omuyungiro gwa RCGP RSC ogw’okulondoola yegu ne tugufuulamu ogwo ogusobola okukebera enkola y’okulwanyisa COVID-19.

sourceString: The extended surveillance has already seen the use of new codes with 3 cases reported.
targetString: Okulondoola okwongezeddwayo kuteereddwamu enkozesa ya koodi empya n’abalwadde 3 ne bamanyibwa.

sourceString: Rapid sharing of this protocol should enable scientific critique and shared learning.
targetString: Okugabana amangu enkola/enseetuka eno kusobola okusobozesa okukolokota kw’ekinnassaayansi wamu n’okuyigira awamu.

sourceString: The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) is a network of general practices (GPs) with a nationally representative population that provides pseudonymized data for weekly surveillance of infectious diseases.
targetString: Ekitongole kya Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) ntabiro ya kukolera wamu (GPs) n’abantu abakiikirira abalala mu ggwanga lyonna abaggyibwako obukwekeze buli wiiki ey’okulondoola endwadde ezisiigibwa.

sourceString: The disease surveillance program is commissioned by Public Health England (PHE) and covers 37 infectious diseases, including influenza.
targetString: Enteekateeka y’okulondoola endwadde yassibwawo Ekitongole ky’Ebyobulamu mu Bungereza (Public Health England (PHE)) era nga kikola ku ndwadde ezisiigibwa 37 omwo nga mwe muli ne yegu.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC and PHE have an established collaboration of over 50 years in influenza and respiratory disease surveillance and are now in their 53rd season of surveillance and analysis.
targetString: RCGP RSC ne PHE birina enkolagana eyassibwawo emaze emyaka egisukka mu 50 mu kukola ku yegu n’endwadde z’omuyungiro gw’okussa era kati bali mu kiseera kya 53 mu kulondoola n’okwekaliriza.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC extracts pseudonymized data from a nationally representative sample of over 500 urban and nonurban GPs each week covering a population of over 4 million.
targetString: RCGP RSC kiggya obubaka obukwekeze okuva mu sampolo ekikiirira eggwanga lyonna okuva mu bantu b’omu bibuga n’abatali ba mu bibuga 500 mu GP buli wiiki okuva mu bantu abasukka mu bukadde 4.

sourceString: Data from these practices are reported online in a weekly return, which includes monitoring weekly rates of influenza-like illness (ILI) and other communicable and respiratory diseases in England.
targetString: Obubaka obuva mu kukola okwo bulagibwa ku muyungiro gwa yintaneeti mu buli wiiki, omuli okulondoola emiwendo gy’obulwadde obwefaananyiriza yegu (influenza-like illness (ILI)) buli wiiki wamu n’endwadde endala ez’omuyungiro gw’okussa mu Bungereza.

sourceString: We also produce an annual report.
targetString: Tukola ne alipoota eya buli mwaka.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC data set includes all coded data and all prescribed items including vaccine exposure.
targetString: Obubaka bwa RCGP RSC bulimu obubaka obuliko ennamba wamu n’ebintu ebirala ebinnyonnyoddwa omuli n’eddagala erigema.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC conducts virology surveillance each influenza season, with 100 GPs participating in the 2019-2020 season (Figure 1).
targetString: RCGP RSC kikola okunoonyereza ku buwuka buli mulundi yegu w’abeerera omungi, nga mulimu GPS 100 ezeetabamu mu kiseera ekya 2019-2020 (Ekifaananyi 1).

sourceString: These virology sampling practices are also recruited to be nationally representative (Figure 1).
targetString: Okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka era kutwalibwa ng’okukiikirira eggwanga lyonna (Ekifaananyi 1).

sourceString: GPs take nasopharyngeal swabs from persons showing acute respiratory illness within 7 days of the onset of symptoms.
targetString: GPs bayisa obuwero mu nnyindo ne mu mimiro (nasopharyngeal swabs) okuva ku bantu abalabikirako obubonero bw’okukosebwa ennyo mu kussa mu bbanga lya nnaku 7 okuva obubonero lwe butandise okubeeyolekerako.

sourceString: Nasopharyngeal swabs are taken from children younger than 5 years showing symptoms of acute bronchitis or bronchiolitis.
targetString: Okuyisa obuwero mu nnyindo ne mu mimiro (nasopharyngeal swabs) kikolebwa ku baana abataweza myaka 5 egy’obukulu abalabikirako obubonero bw’olufuba (acute bronchitis) oba bronchiolitis.

sourceString: Additionally, nasopharyngeal samples are taken from anyone 5 years and older showing acute onset of ILI and respiratory synctial virus.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, sampolo eziggyibwa mu nnyindo ne mu mimiro (nasopharyngeal samples) ziggyibwa ku muntu yenna alina emyaka 5 n’okusingawo alabikirako obubonero bwa ILI obw’amaanyi wamu n’akawuka akayitibwa respiratory synctial virus.

sourceString: Swabs are tested at the PHE Respiratory Virus Unit for influenza to monitor positivity rates and circulating strains, as well as for measuring vaccine effectiveness.
targetString: Obuwero bukebererwa mu kitongole kya PHE Respiratory Virus Unit okulaba oba mulimu yegu okulondoola emiwendo gy’abo abalina obulwadde n’ensaasaana wamu n’okupima enkola y’eddagala erigema.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC successfully conducted a pilot collecting serological samples from adults and linking them to a patient’s medical records during the 2018-2019 influenza season.
targetString: RCGP RSC yakola bulungi okugezesa kw’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’omusaayi (serological samples) okuva mu bantu abakulu n’okuzikwanaganya n’ebiwandiiko by’abalwadde eby’ekisawo mu kiseera kya yegu ekya 2018-2019.

sourceString: This pilot was in collaboration with the PHE Seroepidemiology Unit and added to the residual blood samples submitted to PHE by National Health Service (NHS) laboratories.
targetString: Okugezesa kuno kwakolerwa wamu n’ekitongole kya PHE Seroepidemiology Unit era kwayongera ku sampolo z’omusaayi ogwasigalawo ogwaweerezebwa ku PHE nga kikolebwa amagezeserezo ga National Health Service (NHS) laboratories.

sourceString: Serology can provide important information about background population immunity, and sentinel networks can provide a mechanism for systematic data collection and linkage to medical records and health outcomes.
targetString: Okukebera omusaayi (Serology) kusobola okukuwa obubaka obw’omugaso obukwata ku byafaayo by’obusibage bw’abantu, ate obunyigirizi mu nkolagana (sentinel networks) busobola okuteekawo enkola y’okukuŋŋaanya obubaka n’okukwanya ebiwandiiko by’ekisawo n’ebivaamu.

sourceString: The serology pilot has demonstrated the ability of the network to collect serology samples in adults.
targetString: Okugezesa kw’okukebera amazzi g’omu mubiri (serology) kulaze obusobozi bw’obuyungirizi mu kukuŋŋaanya sampolo mu bantu abakulu.

sourceString: With the COVID-19 outbreak, PHE and RCGP RSC have adapted existing influenza surveillance to monitor the spread of COVID-19 in the community, and this protocol sets out the basis for that collaboration.
targetString: Olw’okubalukawo kwa nawookera wa COVID-19, PHE ne RCGP RSC bikozesezza okulondoola okuliwo ku yegu okulondoola ensaasaana ya COVID-19 mu bantu, era enkola eno y’eteekawo omusingi gw’okukolagana okwo.

sourceString: The primary national strategy for COVID-19 infection is containment, with patients who are at high risk managed via the telephone help system NHS111 and the PHE health protection teams, but the RCGP RSC surveillance is entirely separate.
targetString: Akakodyo akasookerwako ak’eggwanga ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 kwe kumutangira obutasaasaana, mu balwadde abali mu bulabe obw’amaanyi abakolebwako n’okubakubira essimu mu nkola ya NHS111 ey’okubayamba wamu n’abayambi b’ebyobulamu aba PHE, naye okulondoola kwa RCGP RSC kwo kwa njawulo ddala.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC, by extending its established work, will provide virological and serological surveillance to monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community, and assess the effectiveness of the containment strategy.
targetString: RCGP RSC, mu kigaziya emirimu gyakyo gye kikola, kijja kukola ku kulondoola eby’omunda n’eby’omu bitundu ebirala ebikwata ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 wamu n’okwekaliriza enkola y’obukodyo obukozesebwa okulwanyisa obulwadde buno.

sourceString: We would not be working in isolation on this research.
targetString: Tetuyinza kuba nga tukola ffekka ku kunoonyereza kuno.

sourceString: We will share the protocol with UK colleagues and the I-MOVE consortium who have recently obtained EU Horizon 2020 funding from the stream “Advancing knowledge for the clinical and public health response to the novel coronavirus epidemic”.
targetString: Tujja kugabana enkola ne bannaffe ab’omu UK era enzikaanya ya I-MOVE abaafuna emabegako awo ssente z’okunoonyereza eza EU Horizon 2020 okuva mu “Advancing knowledge for the clinical and public health response to the novel coronavirus epidemic”.

sourceString: It is anticipated that great efficiencies in project management will result through this collaboration than that obtained from countries acting alone.
targetString: Kiteeberezebwa nti okukola obulungi okusinga mu nkwata ya pulojeti kujja kuva mu nkolagana eno okusinga bwe kiri mu mawanga agakola gokka.

sourceString: The aim of this study is to identify whether there is undetected community transmission of COVID-19, estimate population susceptibility, and monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community.
targetString: Ekiruubirira ky’okunoonyereza kuno kwe kuzuula oba nga waliwo okusaasaanya kwa COVID-19 mu bantu okutakengeddwa, okuteebereza abantu abali mu buzibu, n’okulondoola abantu ab’omunda n’ab’omu kitundu ekinene omusaasaanidde COVID-19 mu kitundu.

sourceString: The objectives of this study are as follows:
targetString: Ebigendererwa by’okunoonyereza kuno bye bino:

sourceString: To monitor the burden of suspected COVID-19 activity in the community through primary care surveillance and clinical coding of possible COVID-19 cases referred into the containment pathway
targetString: Okusoola okulondoola okuteeberezebwa kwa COVID-19 mu bitundu nga tuyitira mu kulondoola obujjanjabi obusookerwako n’okulamba okw’ekisawo okw’abayinza okuba ne COVID-19 abaweerezebwa mu bifo gye bakuumirwa

sourceString: To provide virological evidence on the presence and extent of undetected community transmission of COVID-19 and monitor positivity rates among individuals presenting ILI or acute respiratory tract infections to primary care
targetString: Okuleeta obubaka obukwata ku kunoonyereza ku buwuka ku kubeerawo wamu n’obusaasaane bw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 wamu n’okulondoola abantu abalina obulwadde mu bantu kinnoomu abeeyolekerako obuzibu bwa ILI oba obuzibu obw’amaanyi obw’omuyungiro gw’okussa mu bujjanjabi obusookerwako

sourceString: To estimate baseline susceptibility to COVID-19 in the community and estimate both symptomatic and asymptomatic exposure rates in the population through seroprevalence monitoring
targetString: Okuteebereza ebisookerwako mu kukosebwa COVID-19 mu kitundu era n’okuteebereza abeeyolekerako obubonero n’abeeyolekerako obubonero mu bantu nga tuyitira mu kulondoola abantu abalina obulwadde (seroprevalence)

sourceString: To pilot implementation of a scheme for collection of convalescent sera with antibody profiles among recovered cases of COVID-19 discharged to the community
targetString: Okugezesa enkozesa y’enkola y’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’abalwadde abagenda bawona nga tukozesa antibody profiles mu balwadde ba COVID-19 abawonye ne basiibulwa ne baddayo mu bitundu byabwe

sourceString: We intend to capture the following.
targetString: Tusuubira okukuŋŋaanya bino wammanga.

sourceString: Clinical workload related to reports of COVID-19 using the codes created to flag cases, those being assessed and where the infection is located are excluded (Figures 2-​-44)
targetString: Emirimu gy’ekisawo egyekwanya ku alipoota za COVID-19 nga tukozesa koodi eziteekebwa ku balwadde, abo abeekalirizibwa ate n’ekifo obulwadde we buli tebibalibwa (Ebifaananyi 2-​-44)

sourceString: Foreign countries visited in the last 28 days
targetString: Amawanga g’ebweru agakyaliddwa mu nnaku 28 eziyise

sourceString: Existing codes that may have utility (Tables 1-​-3).3).
targetString: Koodi eziriwo eziyinza okubeera n’omugaso (Emyeso 1-​-3).3).

sourceString: Many GPs and primary care teams may not realize that important relevant data can be coded.
targetString: Abasawo aba Bulijjo (GPs) bangi n’abakola ku bujjanjabi obusookerwako bayinza obutakirengera nti obubaka obw’omugaso obwetaagisa bwetaagisa okuteekebwako ennamba.

sourceString: There is also the potential during any pandemic to monitor the effectiveness of any transmission control measures.
targetString: Waliwo n’obusobozi mu kiseera kya nawookera okulondoola obulungi bw’enkola z’okutangira okusaasaana kw’obulwadde.

sourceString: Reliable coding of letters and test results that will show an infection has become either confirmed or excluded
targetString: Okuteeka koodi ku bubaka okwesigika ne ku bivudde mu kukebera okunaalaga obulwadde kufuuse okukakasibwa oba okutabalibwa

sourceString: The methods will follow the approach used in the current influenza surveillance system and recent serology study, and includes five components: (1) primary care clinical surveillance; (2) virological surveillance; (3) population serological surveillance; (4) convalescent sera in cases; and (5) data curation.
targetString: Obukodyo bujja kugoberera enkola egobererwa mu kulondoola yegu mu kiseera kino n’okunoonyereza ku musaayi okwakolebwa emabega era kulimu ebintu bitaanu: (1) Okulondoola obujjanjabi obusookerwako; (2) okulondoola obuwuka (virological surveillance); (3) okulondoola okunoonyereza ku musaayi mu bantu; (4) okunooyereza ku balwadde abagenda bawona; ne (5) okukola ku bubaka obukuŋŋaanyiziddwa.

sourceString: The NHS uses the Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) system of coding, which is normally only updated twice annually.
targetString: NHS kikozesa enkola ya Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) ey’okuteekako koodi, ng’enkola eno ezzibwa obuggya emirundi ebiri gyokka buli mwaka.

sourceString: There was added complexity as some computerized medical record (CMR) suppliers use the Read coding systems (Read clinical terms version 3 – CTv3), which is no longer updated.
targetString: Waaliwo n’obuzibu obulala obweyongerako nga ebiwandiiko by’eddwaliro ebimu eby’oku kompyuta (CMR) bikozesa enkola ya Read coding systems (Read clinical terms version 3 – CTv3), ate nga yo tekyazzibwa buggya.

sourceString: Additionally, there were no clinical codes to record COVID-19 in early February 2020.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, tewaaliwo koodi za kisawo okuwandiika COVID-19 mu mwezi Gwokubiri 2020 nga gutandika.

sourceString: Therefore, the two main GP system suppliers added the five terms shown in Table 4 as system-wide local codes.
targetString: Awo nno, Enkola enkulu ebbiri eza ba GP abaweereza baayongeramu ebimiimo bitaanu ebiragiddwa mu Mweso 4 nga koodi z’omu muyungiro ezikozesebwa mu kitundu.

sourceString: A UK emergency release of SNOMED CT concepts for COVID-19 was also subsequently made available across all CMR systems (Table 4).
targetString: Okufulumya okwakolebwa mu UK okwa SNOMED CT concepts for COVID-19 kwateekebwa mu miyungiro gya CMR (Omweso 4).

sourceString: The intention is that these will eventually be mapped to the new SNOMED CT concepts as they become available, allowing recording of relevant data (Multimedia Appendix 1).
targetString: Ekigendererwa kye kino nti oluvannyuma lwa byonna bino bijja kulambiwa ku bitegeero bya SNOMED CT nga bwe binaaba bizuulibwa, ng’obubaka obwetaagisa buwandiikibwa (Ekikookero kya Multimedia 1).

sourceString: The key requirements for this release were the ability to code (Table 4) a case of COVID-19, exposure to risk of infection (travel to an area where there may be a higher risk), contact with anyone infected with COVID-19, a report that a person had been tested for COVID-19, and that the disease had been excluded (likely a negative test).
targetString: Ekyetaagisa ekikulu eky’olufulumya luno bwe busobozi bw’okuteeka ennamba (Omweso 4) ku mulwadde wa COVID-19, okubeera mu bulabe bw’okukwatibwa obulwadde (okugenda mu kifo ewayinza okubeera obulabe obw’amaanyi), okukwatagana n’omuntu yenna alina COVID-19, alipoota etegeeza nti omuntu yali akebeddwa COVID-19, era nti obulwadde bwali tebulabiddwa (nga kirabika talina bulwadde).

sourceString: In addition, practices are now able to code any foreign travel undertaken, including the ability to record visits to multiple countries (implemented February 8, 2020).
targetString: Okwongereza ku ekyo, ebikolebwa kati bisobola okulamba okutambula kwonna omuntu kw’agenzeeko ebweru, omwo nga mwe muli n’obusobozi bw’okuwandiika okukyala mu mawanga ag’enjawulo (kyatandika nga 8 Ogwokubiri 2020).

sourceString: Figures 2-​-44 show the EMIS web implementation.
targetString: Ebifaananyi 2-​-44 biraga enkola ya EMIS ey’oku mutimbagano.

sourceString: Currently, virology samples for influenza surveillance are accompanied by a standard request form.
targetString: Mu kiseera kino, sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka (virology samples) ku kulondoola yegu ziteekebwako foomu eya bulijjo esaba.

sourceString: For COVID-19, we will create a new request form that will record:
targetString: Ku lwa COVID-19, tujja kukola foomu empya ey’okusibirako ewandiikibwamu:

sourceString: Date of onset of symptoms
targetString: Ennaku z’omwezi obubonero lwe butandise

sourceString: Diagnosis of any of the following:
targetString: Okukebera ekimu ku bino wammanga:

sourceString: Acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis in those younger than five years
targetString: Olufuba olw’amaanyi/bronchiolitis mu abo abataweza myaka etaanu

sourceString: Lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI)
targetString: Obuvune mu kitundu ky’omussizo ekya wansi (LRTI)

sourceString: History of fever (Y/N); measured (Y/N); if yes, level
targetString: Ebyafaayo by’omusujja (Yee/Nedda); apimiddwa (Yee/Nedda); bwe kiba yee, eddaala

sourceString: Shortness of breath (Y/N), if measured: oxygen saturation and respiratory rate
targetString: Okubaka omukka (Yee/Nedda), bw’aba apimiddwa: omukka gw’alina mu mubiri n’embiro kw’assiza

sourceString: Recent travel (Y/N); if yes, countries visited in last 14 days
targetString: Okutambula okw’emabegako (Yee/Nedda); bwe kiba yee, amawanga ge yakyalamu mu nnaku 14 eziyise

sourceString: Contact with a named person with confirmed COVID-19 (Y/N) with a free text comment about the level of certainty
targetString: Okukwatagana n’omuntu ayogeddwako alina COVID-19 (Yee/Nedda) nga waliwo ebigambo ebiraga okwekakasa ku bulwadde bw’omuntu oyo

sourceString: These codes will be grouped ontologically into “definite”, “probable”, “possible”, and “not a case” using our standard approach to grouping codes (Table 5), which has been used previously across disease areas.
targetString: Koodi ezo zijja kubinjawazibwa okusinziira nga bwe zajjja mu bibinja nga “kikakasika”, “kirabika”, “kisoboka”, ne “si mulwadde” nga tukozesa enkola yaffe ey’okubinjawaza koodi (Omweso 5), eyakozesebwako emabegako mu bifo by’endwadde.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC definition for ILI is shown in Multimedia Appendix 2.
targetString: Enyinyonnyola ya RCGP RSC eya ILI eragibwa mu Nkookero ya Multimedia 2.

sourceString: Public Presentation of Data Using an Observatory and Dashboards
targetString: Okulaga obubaka mu lwatu omuli Okukozesa Ekyekalirizo (Observatory) ne Dashboards

sourceString: We will develop an observatory to present data nationally and a dashboard for feedback to practices about their data quality and collection of virology and serology samples.
targetString: Tujja kukolawo ekyekalirizo okulagiramu obubaka mu ggwanga lyonna ate ne dashboard tufuniremu ebiva mu bantu ku bikwata ku bikolebwa ku mutindo gw’obubaka n’enkuŋŋaanya y’obubaka obw’okunoonyereza ku buwuka wamu n’okunoonyereza ku musaayi.

sourceString: This is based on coding described in Table 4.
targetString: Kino kyesigamiziddwa ku kuteekako ennamba okulagiddwa mu Mweso 4.

sourceString: Definite case will be presented on our dashboard as “cases” of COVID-19.
targetString: Omulwadde akakasiddwa ajja kulagibwa ku dashboard yaffe nga “abalwadde” ba COVID-19.

sourceString: Possible cases will be presented as “Under investigation” (investigating).
targetString: Abalabika okuba abalwadde bajja kulagibwa nga “Abakyanoonyerezebwako” (okunoonyereza).

sourceString: “Not a case” will be presented as “Excluded”.
targetString: “Si mulwadde” ajja kulagibwa nga “Tateereddwamu”.

sourceString: Online data has been established within the initial few weeks in the COVID-19 Observatory (Figure 5), indicating the overall number of patients and rate per 10,000 patients of cases confirmed or under investigation, as well as where the virus is excluded.
targetString: Obubaka obw’oku mutimbagano bukakasiddwa mu wiiki entono ezaasooka mu Kyekalirizo kya COVID-19 (Ekifaananyi 5), ekiraga omuwendo gw’abalwadde bonna n’ekigero ky’abalwadde ku buli balwadde 10,000 abakakasiddwa oba abakyanoonyerezebwako ate ne mu mbeera akawuka we kataafiibwako.

sourceString: We have the option to move to twice weekly surveillance reports with a scope to change this to daily reporting.
targetString: Tulinawo omukisa gw’okutandika okukolera ku mirundi ebiri mu wiiki nga tukola alipoota z’okulondoola nga tulina n’ebbanga ery’okukyusa ne tudda ku kuwa alipoota buli lunaku.

sourceString: We will continue virology sampling from our sentinel practices, rather than discontinuing as seasonal influenza declines.
targetString: Tujja kweyongera okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka okuva mu bye tukola okunoonyereza ku bitundu omuli obulwadde, mu kifo ky’okubisazaamu ng’ekiseera kya yegu kikendedde.

sourceString: Additionally, we will recruit more surveillance practices.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, tujja kuleeta enkola z’okulondoola endala.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC virology practices will aim to undertake 200-300 nasopharyngeal swabs per week across the RCGP RSC sentinel network, collecting specimens across all age bands.
targetString: RCGP RSC by’ekola ku kunoonyereza ku buwuka bijja kuluubirira okuggya sampolo z’omu nnyindo ne mu kamwa 200-300 buli wiiki mu bitundu bya RCGP RSC byonna bye bakoleramu okulaba ebifo omuli obulwadde, nga bakuŋŋaanya sampolo mu bantu ab’emyaka gyonna.

sourceString: In addition to the inclusion criteria for influenza virology surveillance (ILI, acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis), participating practices will take nasopharyngeal swab samples from any people showing acute symptoms of LRTI if the onset of symptoms is within 7 days.
targetString: Okwongereza ku ky’akakwakkulizo k’okwongeramu okulondoola obuwuka ku yegu (ILI, acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis), abakola bajja kukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’omu nnyindo ne mu kamwa okuva ku bantu ab’engeri yonna abeeyolekerako obubonero bwa LRTI kasita kiba nti obubonero obusoose bulabikidde mu nnaku 7 ezisooka.

sourceString: RCGP RSC research officers and practice liaison staff will manage practices to achieve a total national sample of 200-300 swabs per week.
targetString: Abanoonyereza ba RCGP RSC n’abakola ku nsonga z’abantu bajja kukola ku bikolebwa okufuna sampolo za swab 200-300 mu ggwanga lyonna buli wiiki.

sourceString: This could be increased if PHE modelers require more samples.
targetString: Ziyinza okwongezebwa singa abakola ku PHE beetaaga sampolo endala.

sourceString: Samples from each practice would be spread across the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years and older
targetString: Sampolo okuva mu buli ekikolebwa zijja kuggyibwa mu bantu ab’emyaka egy’enjawulo: abataweza myaka 5, myaka 5-17, myaka 18-64, n’emyaka 65 years n’okusingawo

sourceString: Samples (swabs or serum) collected will be sent via prepaid envelopes addressed to the appropriate PHE laboratory for analysis.
targetString: Sampolo (swabs oba serum) ezinaakuŋŋaanyizibwa zijja kuweerezebwa mu mabaasa aganaaba gamaze okusasulirwa mu magezeserezo ga PHE agasaanidde zeekalirizibwe.

sourceString: All samples collected will be tested for the presence of influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Sampolo zonna ezikuŋŋaanyizibwa zijja kukeberebwa okulaba oba nga mulimu yegu ne COVID-19.

sourceString: Additionally, PHE will retrospectively test any influenza virology samples collected between early and mid-February 2020 for COVID-19.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, PHE kijja kuddayo kikebere sampolo z’obuwuka bwa yegu ezaakuŋŋaanyizibwa mu Gwokubiri wakati, 2020 okulaba oba nga mulimu COVID-19.

sourceString: Practices will still follow the PHE protocol for COVID-19 with respect to people at risk of infection who should be signposted down the containment pathway, rather than physically attend their practice.
targetString: Ebikolebwa PHE bijja kweyongera okugoberera enseetuka ya COVID-19 nga bafaayo ku bantu abali mu buzibu bw’okukwatibwa obulwadde abalina okufiibwako mu kaweefube w’okutangira ekirwadde mu kifo ky’okubatuukako obutereevu.

sourceString: Direct testing of those who attend surgery remains permitted, but we have also rolled out self-swabbing at home.
targetString: Okukebera obutereevu okw’abo abalongoosebwa kukkirizibwa naye nga kati tutaddewo n’entegeka y’omuntu okwekolera swab ewaka.

sourceString: Summary of processes are detailed in Multimedia Appendix 3.
targetString: Ekifunze ky’enkwajja kinnyonnyoddwa mu Kikookero kya Multimedia 3.

sourceString: Everyone with an ILI or a respiratory illness who contacts a GP (eg, phones for an appointment) should be asked specifically about recent travel to China and other countries flagged in current PHE advice, or if they have had contact with other people with COVID-19.
targetString: Buli muntu yenna alina ILI oba obulwadde bw’okussa era ng’atuukiridde GP (okugeza, n’akuba essimu okukola akalagaane) alina okubuuzibwa oba ku ntambula ze yakola emabegako e China ne mu mawanga amalala agalambibwa mu kimanyiso kya PHE, oba bw’aba ng’abadde akwataganyeeko n’abantu abalala abalina COVID-19.

sourceString: If these screening enquiries are positive, the patient would be advised to not come to the practice but instead to follow the PHE flow sheet.
targetString: Okukebera kuno bwe kulaga nti balina obulwadde, omulwadde aweebwa amagezi aleme kujja kumujjanjaba naye agoberere ebiragibwa PHE.

sourceString: This can be by a reception or clinician staff, depending on individual practice protocol.
targetString: Kino kisobola okukolebwa omuntu atuukirwako ku kifo oba omusawo, okusinziira ku nseetuka ya buli omu nga bw’eri.

sourceString: These calls should be coded into the GP CMR system and can be reported as part of the RCGP RSC weekly return.
targetString: Amasimu gano agakubibwa galina okuweebwa ennamba mu muyungiro gwa GP CMR era galina okulagibwa ng’ekitundu ku bikolebwa RCGP RSC buli wiiki.

sourceString: We have developed training material to support this coding (Multimedia Appendix 4).
targetString: Tuteeseteese ebiwandiiko ebitendekerwako okuwagira enkola y’okuteekako ennamba (Ekikookero kya Multimedia 4).

sourceString: These include prompt cards for:
targetString: Muno muzingiramu kaadi ez’amangu eza:

sourceString: Practice reception or triage staff: for coding of any patients calling the practice with symptoms of acute respiratory infection with a history of travel to important areas based on PHE advice
targetString: Abakola ku kifo ewatuukirwa oba abategeka abalwadde: okuwa ennamba omulwadde yenna akuba essimu okufuna obujjanjabi ng’alina obubonero obw’amaanyi mu kussa ate nga yatambulako mu bifo ebikulu okusinziira ku kimanyiso kya PHE

sourceString: Administrative staff or clinicians who code: to encourage consistent coding of results for any suspected cases, including coding of negative results for exclusion
targetString: Abakola ku nsonga z’obukulembeze oba abasawo abateekako ennamba: okuwagira okuteekako ennamba entakera ku biva ku mulwadde yenna ateeberezebwa, omwo nga mwe muli n’okuwa ennamba ebivudde mu kukebera eby’atalina bulwadde byawulwe

sourceString: Practices participating in virology surveillance will opportunistically collect blood samples from patients coming into the practice for a routine blood test.
targetString: Abakola ku kulondoola okunoonyereza ku buwuka bajja kubeera n’omukisa gw’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’omusaayi okuva ku balwadde abakeberwa omusaayi oluvannyuma lw’akaseera.

sourceString: Patients who attend their practice for a routine blood test will be asked to provide an additional sample for serology.
targetString: Abalwadde abagenda okubajjanjaba olw’okubaggyako omusaayi ogwa bulijjo bajja kusabibwa okuwaayo sampolo y’omusaayi omulala olw’okukola okunoonyereza kw’omusaayi.

sourceString: We have conducted initial searches within the RCGP RSC database to look at the number of full blood count (FBC) results and overall rates in adults and children (Figures 6-​-9).9).
targetString: Tukoze okunoonya okusooka mu kkuŋŋaanyizo lya RCGP RSC okulaba omuwendo gw’ebiva kukebera omusaayi okujjuvu (FBC) wamu n’emiwendo egy’awamu mu bantu abakulu n’abaana (Ekifaananyi 6-​-9).9).

sourceString: An FBC is one of the most common tests performed, and we hope this will give an approximate indication of overall numbers of blood tests performed.
targetString: FBC y’emu ku kukebera okukolebwa, era tusuubira nti kino kijja kuwa okuteebereza ku miwendo egy’awamu egy’omusaayi ogukeberwa.

sourceString: The sampling rate, per 100,000 patients was highest for children 15-17 years of age and 60 year or older in adults, with the lowest rates in children 0-4 years of age and 18-29 years of age in adults (Figures 6-​-99).
targetString: Omuwendo ogukebererwako, ku buli balwadde 100,000 gwali waggulu mu baana ab’emyaka 15-17 egy’obukulu n’ab’emyaka 60 oba okusingawo mu bakulu, era ng’omuwendo omutono gwali mu baana ab’emyaka 0-4 egy’boukulu ne 18-29 egy’oubkulu mu bakulu (Ekifaananyi 6-​-99).

sourceString: We will provide 1000 serology baseline samples across all ages that reflect the varying rates of attendance by age.
targetString: Tujja kuwaayo sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku musaayi ezisookerwako 1000 mu bantu ab’emyaka gyonna abalaga enkyukakyuka y’emiwendo gy’abo abakolebwako okusinziira ku myaka.

sourceString: Additionally, we will test if we can obtain these all from virology practices to enhance the yield.
targetString: Okwongereza ku ekyo, tujja kugezesa oba nga tusobola okubifuna byonna okuva mu bujjanjabi bw’okunoonyereza ku musaayi olw’okwongera okunyweza ebizuulibwa.

sourceString: A good geographical spread is important, so PHE can advise on areas where serology will most usefully be collected.
targetString: kikulu nnyo okukolera mu bifo eby’enjawulo, awo nno PHE nakyo kijja kuwa amagezi ku bifo ebigasa okukoleramu okunoonyereza ku musaayi.

sourceString: This will be followed by 800 samples monthly.
targetString: Kino kijja kugobererwa sampolo 800 buli mwezi.

sourceString: The sample will be stratified with 200 specimens for prepandemic survey (100 for monthly) in the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years or older.
targetString: Sampolo ejja kubinjawazibwa mu butu (specimen) 200 mu kunoonyereza nga nawookera tannabaawo (100 buli mwezi) mu bibinja by’emyaka bino: emyaka egitawera 5, emyaka 5-17 , emyaka 18-64 , n’emyaka 65 n’okusingawo.

sourceString: The younger patients, in many practices younger than 14 years, and in nearly all for children younger than 8 years will require pediatric serology surveillance.
targetString: Abalwadde ab’emyaka emimpi, mu kunoonyereza okusinga nga tebaweza myaka 14, ate ne mu kunoonyereza kumpi kwonna ku baana abataweza myaka 8 bajja kwetaaga okulondoola kw’okunoonyereza ku musaayi mu baana abato.

sourceString: We will develop a new request form for practices to capture recent travel and exposure to COVID-19.
targetString: Tujja kukola foomu y’okusaba empya ey’obujjanjabi okufunirako ebikwata ku kutambula okwakolebwa emabegako n’okukwatagana ne COVID-19.

sourceString: We will pilot a scheme for collecting convalescent serology from people with confirmed cases and who have had an acute virology sample at the time of their infection.
targetString: Tujja kukola okugeza kw’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’abalwadde abagenda bawona okunoonyereza ku musaayi gwabwe okuva mu bantu abaakakasibwa nti balwadde ate nga balina sampolo y’obuwuka obw’amaanyi mu kiseera obulwadde we bwabakwatira.

sourceString: This is to identify a carrier state in patients who have recovered from the virus but may continue shedding the virus.
targetString: Kino kijja kuyambako mu kumanya embeera y’abalwadde abalina akawuka abawonye akawuka naye nga bayinza okweyongera okubeera n’akawuka.

sourceString: If there are a small number of cases, this may assist in developing a test kit for patients to take to their own GP and explore its acceptability to patients.
targetString: Bwe kiba nga waliwo abalwadde batono, kino kiyinza okuyamba mu kukulaakulanya ekiyamba mu kukebera mu balwadde okutwala eri omusawo waabwe era ne bekkaanya engeri abalwadde baabwe gye bakirabamu.

sourceString: If there are a large number of COVID-19 cases nationally, convalescent samples could be collected from RCGP RSC practices where there are confirmed cases, with the ability to link to the full medical record.
targetString: Bwe waba nga waliwo ennamba y’abalwadde ba COVID-19 nnene mu ggwanga lyonna, sampolo z’abalwadde abagenda bawona okuva mu bifo bya RCGP RSC bye baakakasibwa nti balwadde, n’obusobozi bw’okubikwataganaya n’ebiwandiiko by’ekisawo.

sourceString: This process may include checking pseudonymized NHS numbers for positive individuals at RCGP RSC practices, checking current PHE guidance regarding considerations of infectiousness for confirmed cases, and offering the patient an appointment following the previously mentioned process.
targetString: Omutendera guno guyinza okubaamu okukebera ennamba za NHS enkwekeze ez’abantu abalina obulwadde mu bifo bya RCGP RSC, okukebera okuluŋŋamya kwa PHE okuliwo okukwata ku kufaayo ku kusiiga obulwadde ku balwadde abakakasiddwa, n’okulaga omulwadde lw’anajja ku ddwaliro nga bagoberera enkwajja eyayogerwako emabega.

sourceString: This needs to be carefully coordinated nationally across the network and may require PHE to ensure individuals are not contacted by multiple agencies.
targetString: Kino kirina okukolebwako n’obwegendereza mu ggwanga lyonna mu ntabiro yonna era kiyinza okwetaagisa PHE okukakasa nti abantu tebatuukirirwa bitongole bya njawulo bingi.

sourceString: RCGP RSC could provide a useful structure to channel the initial contact once PHE has made a request.
targetString: RCGP RSC kiyinza okulaga enkola ey’omugaso ey’okuweereza omuntu eyasooka okukwataganibwa naye kasita PHE ekola okusaba.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of a LRTI.
targetString: Ebikolebwa RCGP RSC mu kunoonyereza ku kulondoola obuwuka bwa yegu okwa buli mwaka batandise okukuŋŋaanya sampolo okuva mu balwadde abeeyolekerako obubonero bwa LRTI.

sourceString: All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Sampolo zonna ezaafunibwa zikeberebwa okulaba oba nga mulimu yegu ne COVID-19.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC will explore ways to collect convalescent samples from any patients tested positive for COVID-19 through the extension of the virological surveillance.
targetString: RCGP RSC kijja kwekaliriza engeri y’okukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’abalwadde abagenda bawona okuva mu mulwadde yenna eyakeberebwa ng’alina COVID-19 nga kiyitira mu kwongezaayo okulondoola ku kunoonyereza ku buwuka.

sourceString: From the start, we will be carefully curating data to ensure that it can be used for future studies.
targetString: Okuva olubereberye, tujja kwegendereza mu kwekaliriza obubaka tukakase nti busobola okukozesebwa mu kunoonyereza okujja mu maaso.

sourceString: Our clinical data will be linked to virology.
targetString: Obubaka bwaffe obw’ekisawo bujja kukwanyizibwa n’obwo obw’okunoonyereza ku musaayi.

sourceString: We will curate our data using the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles.
targetString: Tujja kwekaliriza obubaka bwaffe nga tukozesa emisingi gya Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable.

sourceString: To facilitate this our data set is listed with Health Data Research UK and the European Health Data Evidence Network.
targetString: Kino okukisobozesa obubaka bwaffe butegekeddwa wamu n’obwa Health Data Research UK ne European Health Data Evidence Network.

sourceString: The statistical methodology is in support of a policy approach to widespread disease outbreak, where so-called nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) are used to respond to an emerging pandemic to produce disease suppression.
targetString: Akakodyo k’ebibalo kawagira enkola y’okukwatamu nawookeera w’endwadde abunye wonna, omuli okukozesa enkola ezitaliimu ddagala (NPIs) okwaŋŋanga ekirwadde ekibaluseewo okufuna amagezi agalwanyisa ekirwadde.

sourceString: This policy aims to reduce contact rates in the population and thereby reduce transmission of the virus.
targetString: Enkola eno eruubirira okukendeeza ku muwendo gw’okukwatagana mu bantu era mu ngeri eyo okusaasaanya akawuka ne kukendeera.

sourceString: To implement this the UK government has recently articulated the desire to implement population self-isolation measures.
targetString: Okussa kino mu nkola, gavumenti ya UK emabegako awo yalaga obwetaavu bw’okussa mu nkola enkola y’abantu okweggya mu bannaabwe.

sourceString: By targeting the reproduction number (R) (the average number of secondary cases each case generates) and aiming to reduce the R to below 1, the policy seeks to reduce case numbers to low levels or (as seen in previous outbreaks with severe acute respiratory syndrome and Ebola) to eliminate human-to-human transmission.
targetString: Nga tutunuulira ennamba y’okuzaalukana (R) (omuwendo omukkati ogw’abalwadde abasiigibwa buli mulwadde gw’aleeta) ate n’okuluubirira okukendeeza omuwendo (R) gubeere wansi wa 1, enkola eruubirira okukendeeza omuwendo gw’abalwadde gukke wansi oba (nga bwe kyalabibwa mu bulwadde obwabalukawo emabegako omwali obuzibu obw’amaanyi mu muyungiro gw’okussa ne Ebola) okumalawo okusaasaanya kw’obulwadde okw’okuva ku muntu omu okudda ku mulala.

sourceString: As the experience from the 2009 H1N1 pandemic has shown, NPIs can be a crucial component of pandemic mitigation.
targetString: Ng’obumanyirivu ku nawookeera wa 2009 H1N1 bwe bulaze, NPIs kiyinza okubeera ekirungi eky’amaanyi mu kutangira nawookeera.

sourceString: Key to the focus of our study will be the estimation of peak cases in the population and continual monitoring by data collection and modelling the potential growth and emergence of subsequent peaks in new cases as social distancing measures are relaxed.
targetString: Ekintu ekikulu mu kuweefube w’okunoonyereza kwaffe kijja kuba okuteebereza abalwadde ennyo mu bantu wamu n’okulondoola entakera nga tutunuulira enkuŋŋaanya y’obubaka n’enkolako yaabwo mu kulengera okweyongera kw’obulwadde n’okulaba oba nga bweyongera mu balwadde abapya amateeka g’obuteerinaana bwe ganaagenda nga gawewulwa.

sourceString: There has already been publication of important disease epidemiological measures concerning the outbreak of COVID-19 in mainland China.
targetString: Waliwo okunoonyereza okumaze okufulumizibwa ku kukwata ku bulwadde n’ebikolebwa ku kubalukawo kwa COVID-19 mu ggwanga lya China.

sourceString: A further fundamental measure in pandemic dynamics is the length of time from infection to when a person is infectious to others and the mean duration of infectiousness.
targetString: Ekintu ekirala ekikulu ekikolebwa mu kwaŋŋanga nawookeera bwe buwanvu bw’ebbanga okuva omuntu lw’abufunye ne w’atandikidde okubusiiga abalala wamu n’ebbanga ly’amala ng’abusiiga.

sourceString: These factors, if estimated accurately, will give good predictions for the likely length of the pandemic, the final number of infected cases.
targetString: Ensonga zino bwe ziteeberezebwa obulungi zijja kuwa okuteebereza okulungi ku bbanga nawookeera ono ly’anaamala, omuwendo ogusembayo ogw’abalwadde.

sourceString: We intend to apply approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.
targetString: Tusuubira okukozesa enkola za approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.

sourceString: Such techniques are highly parallelizable and have been successfully applied to many fields including disease transmission modelling.
targetString: Obukodyo obw’engeri eyo bwawulibwa nnyo mu nneekaliriza era bukozeseddwa bulungi mu bisaawe bingi omwo nga mwe muli n’okuteebereza ensaasaana y’obulwadde.

sourceString: They are particularly suited to situations where likelihood functions are absent and where more traditional approaches such as Markov chain Monte Carlo are impractical.
targetString: Bukozesebwa mu ngeri emu mu mbeera enteebereza ey’omugaso w’etabeererawo ate ne mu mbeera enkola eza bulijjo gamba nga Markov chain Monte Carlo nga tezisobola kukola.

sourceString: Such an approach has been demonstrated to work effectively on the ASPREN surveillance data, a network of sentinel GPs and nurse practitioners who report deidentified information on ILIs and other conditions, where issues such as missing data and the need to model the observation process itself has been successfully addressed.
targetString: Enkola ey’engeri eyo eraze nti ekola bulungi ku kulondoola kw’obubaka bwa ASPREN, enkolagana ya GPs ey’ekiraga okubaawo kw’obulwadde n’abajjanjabi abategeeza obubaka obukwekeze ku ILIs n’embeera endala, awali ensonga gamba nga obubaka obutaliiwo n’obwetaavu bw’okukola ku nkwajja y’okwekaliriza yennyini ekoleddwako bulungi.

sourceString: Furthermore, peaks in new cases have been estimated by distributional methods.
targetString: Ekirala, okutumbuka mu balwadde abapya kubadde kuteeberezebwa na nbukodyo bwa busaasaane.

sourceString: Estimates of the parameters of the SEIR model are tractable on large data sets because of parallelizability, and these methods have been implemented in several R libraries; we intend to use the libraries ABSEIR (deposited on GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) and abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) to estimate epidemic measures on a weekly basis.
targetString: Okuteebereza kw’obukodyo bwa SEIR model tekukola ku bubaka bungi olw’okuba nti busobola okwawulibwa era obukodyo buno bukozeseddwa mu magezeserezo mangi aga R libraries; tusuubira okukozesa libraries ABSEIR (ng’esangibwa ku GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) ne abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) okuteebereza empima ya nawookeera buli wiiki.

sourceString: Since we are fitting an SIR-epidemic model in the ABC routine, we anticipate that our results will be robust against weekly case data containing relatively small counts.
targetString: Olw’okuba nga tugyisa enkola ya SIR-epidemic model mu nkola ya ABC, tusuubira nti ebinaazuulibwa bijja kuba binnyonnyola bulungi obubaka bw’abalwadde obwa buli wiiki omuli emiwendo emitonoko.

sourceString: For example, see for the ABC methodology applied to the Tristan da Cunha common cold data from 1967, where counts of I (number of infectious cases) and R (number of recovered cases) are in the tens at most.
targetString: Okugeza, laba enseetuka ya ABC eyateekebwa ku bubaka bwa ssennyiga wa Tristan da Cunha common cold mu 1967, omwali omuwendo gwa I (omuwendo ogw’abalwadde abasiiga) ne R (omuwendo gw’abalwadde abaawona) gwali awo okusinga ennyo mu makumi.

sourceString: Finally, in addition to the above methodology we will employ the Kaplan-Meier method with two outcomes (death and recovery) to estimate the case fatality ratio.
targetString: Ekisembayo, ng’oggyeeko akakodyo akoogeddwako waggulu tujja kukozesa enkola ya Kaplan-Meier omuli ebivaamu eby’emirundi ebiri (okufa n’okuwona) okuteebereza omuwendo gw’abalwadde abafa.

sourceString: This approach is independent of the ABC methodology and will allow comparisons between estimates from the two modelling approaches to judge robustness of results.
