targetString: Enkola eno yeemalirira ku eyo eya ABC era ejja kukkiriza okugeraageranya wakati w’okuteebereza okuva mu njolekera z’okuteebereza zombi okulamula obunnyiinyiitivu bw’ebizuuliddwa.

sourceString: RCGP RSC’s surveillance with PHE is defined as Health Protection under Regulation 3 of The Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002.
targetString: Okulondoola kwa RCGP RSC ne PHE kunnyonnyolwa nga Okwerinda mu Byobulamu mu Tteeka 3 erya Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002.

sourceString: This has been confirmed by PHE’s Caldicott Guardian’s Office.
targetString: Kino kyakakasibwa Wofiisi ya PHE Caldicott Guardian.

sourceString: We do not see any increased risk to practices or practitioners taking part in this surveillance.
targetString: Tetulaba kweyongera kwa bulabe ku bikolebwa oba abakola mu kitundu kino eky’okulondoola.

sourceString: Infection prevention and control advice will follow extant national guidance.
targetString: Okuziyiza okusiigibwa obulwadde n’okutangira kujja kugoberera okuluŋŋamizibwa okw’eggwanga lyonna.

sourceString: Any cases identified will be managed according to the PHE/NHS guidance in force at the time, including advice for identified contacts.
targetString: Abalwadde bonna abanaalabibwa bajja kukolebwako okusinziira ku kuluŋŋamizibwa okunaabaawo mu kiseera ekyo, omwo nga mwe muli amagezi ku bantu be banaaba bakwataganye nabo.

sourceString: However, our training will include reminders about safe handling of specimens and revision of infection control measures anticipated to be high in our practices.
targetString: Wabula, okutendeka kwaffe kujja kuzingiramu okujjukiza ku nkwata ya specimen ennungi n’okwejjukanya ku kutangira okusiigibwa ebintu ebisuubira okubeera eby’amaanyi mu bye tukola.

sourceString: It is a key part of Regulation 12 about safe care and treatment, periodically inspected by the Care Quality Commission.
targetString: Kitundu kikulu mu Teeka 12 erikwata ku kwegendereza n’obujjanjabi era nga lirondoolwa buli kiseera Akakiiko Akakola ku by’Omutindo (Care Quality Commission).

sourceString: Travel History and Clinical Descriptors of the COVID-19 Infections
targetString: Ebyafaayo ku ntambula n’Ebinnyonnyola Obulwadde bwa COVID-19

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices have been advised on the clinical coding that has been made available for COVID-19 across all CMR systems.
targetString: Abajjanjabi ba RCGP RSC baweereddwa amagezi ku nkola y’okukozesa koodi mu ddwaliro eteereddwawo olw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 ku miyungiro gya CMR gyonna.

sourceString: This includes information on coding of clinical descriptors (Table 4) and any recent travel history.
targetString: Muno mulimu obubaka obukwata ku binnyonnyola enkozesa ya koodi (Omweso 4) n’ebikwata ku kutambula kwonna okw’emabegako.

sourceString: Establishment of Extended Virology Sampling
targetString: Okumanya ebikwata ku sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka okwongezeddwayo

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of LRTI.
targetString: Abajjanjabi ba RCGP RSC abeetabye mu kulondoola kwa buli mwaka okw’obuwuka bwa yegu batandise okukuŋŋaanya sampolo ku balwadde abeeyolekerako obubonero bwa LRTI.

sourceString: All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Sampolo zonna ezifunibwa zikeberebwa okulaba oba nga mulimu yegu ne COVID-19.

sourceString: This has led to initial early identification of background spread in low-risk patients.
targetString: Kino kireeseewo okukenga okusookerwako mu kusaasaanya mu balwadde ab’obulabe obutono.

sourceString: As of March 7, 2020, the surveillance system has detected 2 cases of COVID-19 in low-risk patients with no history of travel through extended virological sampling.
targetString: Nga 7 Ogwokusatu 2020, omuyungiro gw’okulondoola guzudde abalwadde ba COVID-19 2 mu balwadde abali mu bulabe obutono ate nga tebatambulangako era nga bafuniddwa nga bayitira mu kukuŋŋaanya sampolo z’okunoonyereza ku buwuka.

sourceString: This protocol describes how we have adapted a national influenza surveillance system to monitor community spread of an unexpected infection of COVID-19.
targetString: Enseetuka eno ennyonnyola engeri gye tukozesaamu omuyungiro gw’okulondoola yegu mu nkola ey’okulondoola ensaasaana ya COVID-19 mu bitundu abantu gye babeera.

sourceString: We have rapidly created and incorporated new codes to allow data recording, and are collecting data to monitor the effectiveness of containment strategies.
targetString: Ku mbiro ez’amangu tukoze era ne tuteekamu koodi empya okusobozesa okuwandiika obubaka, era tukuŋŋaanya obubaka okulondoola enkola y’obukodyo bw’okutangira nawookeera.

sourceString: Through this surveillance, we intend to find out more about the epidemiology of COVID-19 in ambulatory care.
targetString: Mu kulondoola kuno, tulowooza okuzuula ebisingawo ebikwata ku nfaanana ya COVID-19 mu bujjanjabi obw’okutuuka ku bantu.

sourceString: In particular, its rate of spread, both temporal and geographical.
targetString: Okusinga ennyo, embiro kwe katambulira munda mu ggwanga ate mu bitundu ebirala.

sourceString: Our testing of low-risk patients will also inform whether the containment strategy that is based on virology testing of high-risk patients and their contacts plus self-isolation is effective.
targetString: Okukebera kwaffe okw’abalwadde abatalina bulabe bwa maanyi nakwo kujja kulaga oba ng’obukodyo bw’okulwanyisa nawookeera obwesigamziddwa ku kukebera omusaayi gw’abalwadde abalina obuzibu obw’amaanyi n’abo be bakwataganye nabo wamu n’omuntu okweggya mu banne bukola bulungi.

sourceString: Containment should slow the spread, and there may be benefits in the management of spread from intense surveillance.
targetString: Okulwanyisa obulwadde kulina okukendeeza ku kukusaasaana kw’obulwadde era wayinza okubaawo emiganyulo mu kukola ku kusaasaana nga kuva ku kulondoola okw’amaanyi.

sourceString: However, there may come a point at which the virus spreads more widely into the population, as has happened in Italy.
targetString: Wabula, wayinza okubaawo ekiseera akawuka we kasaasaanira ennyo mu bantu, nga bwe kibadde mu Italy.

sourceString: Surveillance of low-risk patients should inform when we reach this tipping point and when infection rates start to remit.
targetString: Okulondooal abalwadde abali mu bulabe obutono kulina okutegeeza lwe tulina okutuuka ku ntikko eno ate n’ekiseera emiwendo gy’okukwatibwa obulwadde lwe gitandika okukka.

sourceString: The epidemiology of COVID-19 remains emergent.
targetString: Ebikwata ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 bikyasoomooza okutegeera.

sourceString: The registration-based nature of UK primary care means that we will be able to create a complete picture of the cumulative incidence and duration.
targetString: Obujjanjabi bwa UK obusookerwako obwesigamiziddwa ku kwewandiisa kutegeeza tujja kusobola okusiiga ekifaananyi ekijjuvu eky’obulwadde bwonna n’ebbanga lye bumaze.

sourceString: The surveillance system should be able to identify areas where COVID-19 spread is taking place that might be suitable for trials of antiviral therapy.
targetString: Omuyungo gw’okulondoola guteekwa okuba nga gusobola okukenga ebitundu COVID-19 gy’asaasaanira ebiyinza okuba ebirungi okukolerayo okugezesa eddagala erigema akawuka.

sourceString: We could also follow up on the effectiveness or any adverse reactions to these medicines or vaccinations.
targetString: Tuyinza era okulondoola obukozi n’obulabe obw’engeri yonna obuleetebwa eddagala erijjanjaba oba erigema.

sourceString: Finally, early detection of a confirmed COVID-19 case has exemplified the rapid implementation of this enhanced surveillance in the national network.
targetString: Ekisembayo, okuzuula amangu omulwadde wa COVID-19 kiraze obulungi bw’okussa amangu mu nkola omulimu guno ogw’okulondoola mu ggwanga lyonna.

sourceString: Safety of practices is our primary concern.
targetString: Eky’okuba ng’ebikolebwa tebiriimu bulabe kye kigendererwa kyaffe ekisookerwako.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC has operated for over 50 years and has been involved in collecting samples to monitor disease and vaccine effectiveness through the Hong Kong flu pandemic of 1968/69, the Russian flu of 1977/78, and the 2009 Swine flu pandemic.
targetString: RCGP RSC ebadde enkola okumala emyaka egisukka mu 50 era ebadde yeenyigira mu kukuŋŋaanya sampolo okulondoola obulungi bw’endwadde n’eddagala erigema ng’eyita mu Hong Kong flu pandemic of 1968/69, the Russian flu of 1977/78, ne 2009 Swine flu pandemic.

sourceString: We are not aware of any increased risk to practice staff or other patients from involvement in surveillance.
targetString: Tetukimanyiiko nti waali wabaddewo obulabe eri abasawo oba abalwadde abalala olw’okwenyigira mu kunoonyereza.

sourceString: Pandemic preparedness is part of the role of the RCGP RSC.
targetString: Okwetegekera ekizibu ky’obulwadde kye kimu ku mirimu gya RCGP RSC.

sourceString: It is plausible that enhanced coding of information from contacts with the practices in RCGP RSC will reduce the likelihood of people who may be suspected COVID-19 cases being brought to the surgery inadvertently.
targetString: Kisoboka okuba nti okulamba obulungi ebikwata ku bantu abasemberera emirimu gya RCGP RSC kijja kukendeeza obusobozi bw’abantu abayinza okuteeberezebwa okuba ne COVID-19 okuleetebwa mu ddwaliro mu butanwa.

sourceString: Where cases are detected unexpectedly, it is probably helpful for that patient, their contacts, and the practice to know.
targetString: Mu mbeera ng’abalwadde bazuuliddwa mu ngeri ebadde tesuubirwa, kya mugaso eri omulwadde oyo, abo abamusemberedde, n’abasawo okumanya.

sourceString: The impact on practices has been to close for a day, if a case is found, for deep cleaning and then reopen.
targetString: Ekibaddenga kikolebwa kwe kuggalawo okumala olunaku, nga waliwo omulwadde azuuliddwa, olw’okulongoosa okw’amaanyi ate ne baggulawo oluvannyuma.

sourceString: The principal limitations of our system are the number of data points.
targetString: Obuzibu obusinga obunene mu nkola yaffe gwe muwendo gw’ebifo by’obubaka ebingi.

sourceString: We are collecting serology and virology data from 100 sites, which covers a small group of the population.
targetString: Tukuŋŋaanya obubaka bw’amazzi g’omubiri n’obuwuka (serology and virology data) okuva mu bifo 100, nga bino bikwata ku kibinja kitono ku bantu be tulina okunoonyerezaako.

sourceString: This has been satisfactory for monitoring influenza, but we are not certain if this is a sufficiently large sample for the COVID-19 outbreak.
targetString: Kino kibadde kimatiza mu kulondoola ssenyiga, naye tetukakasa oba ng’omuwendo gwa sampolo guno munene ekimala ku kizibu kya COVID-19.

sourceString: Our sites (surveillance practices) are currently fixed, and it could be helpful to be able to rapidly onboard practices in regions where there are more cases.
targetString: Ebifo byaffe (surveillance practices) mu kiseera kino bigere, era nga kyandibadde kiyamba okusobola okugattako mu bwangu emirimu egikolebwa mu bitundu ewali abalwadde abangi.

sourceString: Currently, we will be reporting weekly.
targetString: Mu kiseera kino, tujja kuba tufulumya alipoota buli wiiki.

sourceString: Our existing system can be enhanced to twice weekly, but maybe daily or hourly data should be our current approach.
targetString: Enkola yaffe esobola okutumbulwa n’edda ku mirundi ebiri mu wiiki, naye ng’oboolyawo obubaka obwa buli lunaku oba buli ssaawa bwe twandibadde tuddako mu kiseera kino.

sourceString: Opportunistic sampling for serology in children younger than 10 years might be limited due to the overall reduced rate of blood tests in children.
targetString: Okuggya sampolo z’amazzi g’omu mubiri mu baana abataweza myaka 10 kiyinza okukaluba olw’okukendeera kw’okukebera omusaayi mu baana okutwaliza awamu.

sourceString: The extended surveillance using the RCGP RSC-PHE network for the emergent COVID-19 outbreak has been established rapidly.
targetString: Okugaziya okulondoola mu kukozesa enkola ya RCGP RSC-PHE ku bulwadde bwa COVID-19 obwabaluseewo kuteereddwawo mu bwangu.

sourceString: The model of getting the appropriate informatics to enable capture of the required data has already been a success, with data recording starting the week the codes were created.
targetString: Enkola y’okufuna obubaka obutuufu okuyamba okufuna obubaka obwetaagibwa mu kiseera kino ekoze bulungi, ng’obubaka bwatandika okufunibwa mu wiiki ennamba mwe zaatondebwawo.

sourceString: In addition, modifying the existing surveillance system to collect population data in a parallel way has also been effective.
targetString: Okwongereza ku ekyo, okulongoosa mu nkola y’okulondoola eriwo okukuŋŋaanya obubaka okuva ku bantu abanoonyerezebwako mu kiseera kyekimu nakyo kikoze bulungi.

sourceString: However, we are at present unsure as to whether the scale of this surveillance provides sufficient data to drive local containment strategies or if reporting infrequently meets the need of our information age.
targetString: Wabula, mu kiseera kino tetunnakakasa oba ng’omutendera gw’okulondoola gwe tuliko gutuwa obubaka obumala okufuna enkola z’okulwanyisa ekizibu oba okutegeeza obubaka ebbalirirwe kimala mu kiseera kino kye tulimu.

sourceString: National Basketball Association suspends season due to COVID-19 concerns
targetString: Ekibiina kya National Basketball Association kiyimirizza emizannyo gyakyo olwa COVID-19

sourceString: On Wednesday, the United States' National Basketball Association (NBA) suspended its professional basketball season due to concerns regarding COVID-19.
targetString: Ku Lwokusatu, ekibiina kya United States' National Basketball Association (NBA) kyayimiriza emizannyo gyakyo egy’ekiseera kino olw’ensonga ezikwata ku COVID-19.

sourceString: The NBA's decision followed a Utah Jazz player testing positive for the COVID-19 virus.
targetString: Okusalawo kw’ekibiina kya NBA's kwazze oluvannyuma lw’omuzannyi wa Utah Jazz okukeberebwa ng’alina akawuka ka COVID-19.

sourceString: The NBA did not release the identity of the player in question in its announcement.
targetString: Ekibiina kya NBA tekyafulumizza mannya ga muzannyi oyo mu kirango kyakyo.

sourceString: They did say he was not present at Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City, where the Utah Jazz were to play against the Oklahoma City Thunder.
targetString: Baagambye nti teyaliiyo mu luzannya lwabwe mu Chesapeake Energy Arena mu Oklahoma City, Utah Jazz gye yabadde alina okuzannyira ne Oklahoma City Thunder.

sourceString: According to its press release, the NBA was "suspending game play following the conclusion of [Wednesday's] schedule of games until further notice."
targetString: Okusinziira ku kiwandiiko kye baafulumizza, NBA "kyayimirizza enzannya zaakyo oluvannyuma lw’okusalawo kwe baatuuseeko [ku Lwokusatu] ku nzannya zaabwe okutuusa lwe banaddamu okusalawo ku nsonga eno."

sourceString: The Jazz's game was cancelled, as was another NBA game Wednesday between the Sacramento Kings and the New Orleans Pelicans.
targetString: Oluzannya lwa Jazz lwasaziddwamu era nga bwe kyali ne ku luzannya olulala olwa NBA olwaliwo ku Lwokusatu wakati wa Sacramento Kings ne New Orleans Pelicans.

sourceString: Other games scheduled for Wednesday were still held, according to NBC News.
targetString: Emizannyo emirala egyaliyo ku Lwokusatu gyo gyagenda mu maaso okusinziira ku mawulire ga NBC News.

sourceString: The United States' other major basketball organization, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which runs college basketball, has cancelled its own tournament, March Madness, for both men's and women's leagues.
targetString: Ekibiina ekirala ekya United States eky’omupiira ogw’ensero, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, ekiddukanya ensero y’ettendekero, kisazizzaamu empaka zaakyo, March Madness, ez’abasajja n’ez’abakazi.

sourceString: According to Johns Hopkins University, as of Wednesday, there were at least 1,279 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the United States.
targetString: Okusinziira ku Johns Hopkins University, ku Lwokusatu waaliwo waakiri abalwadde ba COVID-19 abaali bakakasiddwa mu United States.

sourceString: CNBC reported there were at least 118,381 cases worldwide.
targetString: CNBC kyategeezezza nti mu nsi yonna mulimu abalwadde waakiri 118,381.

sourceString: US President Trump declares COVID-19 national emergency
targetString: Pulezidenti wa US Trump alangiridde COVID-19 ng’ekiziu ky’eggwanga lyonna

sourceString: On Friday, United States President Donald Trump declared a national emergency in response to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.
targetString: Ku Lwokutaanu, Pulezidenti wa America Donald Trump yalangirira ekizibu eky’awamu eky’okubalukawo kwa coronavirus.

sourceString: The move came two days after the World Health Organization declared the outbreak, which causes the COVID-19 disease, to be a pandemic.
targetString: Kino yakikola oluvannyuma lw’ekitongole ky’ensi yonna eky’Ebyobulamu okulangirira okubalukawo kw’obulwadde bwa COVID-19 nga nawookeera.

sourceString: The move gives the federal government access to around US$50 billion in extra funding to combat the pandemic, according to NBC News.
targetString: Amawulire ga NBC News gaategeeza nti ekyakolebwa kino kisobozesa gavumenti ez’ebitundu okuweebwa ssente eziwera ng’obuwumbi bwa doola 50 okulwanyisa nawookeera ono.

sourceString: The proclamation specifically said "the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States constitutes a national emergency" and said the national emergency began on March 1, almost two weeks before the proclamation itself.
targetString: Ekirangiriro ekyo kyagamba nti "okubalukawo kwa COVID-19 mu America kizibu kya wamu mu ggwanga" era n’agamba nti ekizibu ky’eggwanga kyatandika nga 1 Ogwokusatu, kumpi nga wayise wiiki bbiri nga tekinnaba kulangirirwa ng’ekizibu.

sourceString: The United States Department of Health and Human Services declared the outbreak a "public health emergency" on January 31.
targetString: Ekitongole kya America eky’Ebyobulamu (United States Department of Health and Human Services) kyalangirira okubalukawo nga "ekizibu ky’ebyobulamu mu bantu bonna" nga 31 Janwali 31.

sourceString: Trump did not place the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in charge of the government's response to COVID-19, which Politico reported left some experts in disaster management disappointed.
targetString: Trump teyateeka kizibu kya COVID-19 mu mikono gy’ekitongole ekikola ku butyabaga ekiyitibwa Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), ekintu abakugu kye bagamba nti kyabamalamu amaanyi nga Politico bwe yategeeza.

sourceString: Politico quoted Tim Manning, formerly a deputy administrator at FEMA, as saying "FEMA has an important role in coordinating the larger response to the crisis" and "[i]f there's an emergency, FEMA needs to be involved."
targetString: Politico yalaga ebigambo bya Tim Manning, eyali omumyuka w’omukulembeze wa FEMA, ng’agamba nti "FEMA kirina omulimu omukulu mu kukwasaganya ebirina okukolebwa ebisinga obungi ku kizibu" era nti "[singa] wabaawo ekizibu eky’amangu, FEMA kirina okwenyigiramu."

sourceString: Trump made the decision under provisions of the National Emergencies Act, amongst other governing authorities.
targetString: Trump yakola okusalawo okwo ng’asinziira mu Tteeka ly’Ebizibu eby’amangu, National Emergencies Act, omwo nga mwe muli n’ebyobuyinza ebirala ebigobererwa.

sourceString: The Trump administration also announced other efforts in response to COVID-19, including waiving the interest it collects on federal student loans and increasing U.S. strategic oil reserve oil purchases.
targetString: Obukulembeze bwa Trump era bwalangirira kaweefube omulala mu kulwanyisa COVID-19, omuli okuggya amagoba ge baggya ku looni z’abayizi mu gavumenti z’ebitundu wamu n’okwongeza ku mafuta ga U.S. agaterekebwa.

sourceString: Impact of the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic on education
targetString: Engeri nawookeera wa coronavirus owa 2019–20 gy’akosezzaamu ebyenjigiriza

sourceString: The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic has affected educational systems worldwide, leading to the widespread closures of schools and universities.
targetString: Nawookeera wa coronavirus owa 2019–20 akosezza ebitongole by’ebyenjigiriza mu nsi yonna era nga kino kiviiriddeko amasomero ne yunivaasite okuggalwa.

sourceString: As of 8 April 2020, approximately 1.716 billion learners have been affected due to school closures in response to COVID-19.
targetString: Nga 8 Ogwokuna 2020 we lwatuukira, abayizi abakunukkiriza mu kawumbi 1.716 baali bakoseddwa olw’okuggala amasomero olw’okwewala COVID-19.

sourceString: According to UNESCO monitoring, 188 countries have implemented nationwide closures and 5 have implemented local closures, impacting about 99.4%  of the world's student population.
targetString: Okusinziira ku bulondoozi bw’Ekitongole kya UNESCO, amawanga 188 gaggala amasomero gonna ate amawanga 5 go gaggala mu bitundu bimu na bimu, kino ne kikosa ebitundu nga 99.4%  eby’abayizi mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: On 23 March 2020, Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) released a statement announcing the cancellation of Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, and Cambridge Pre-U examinations for the May/June 2020 series across all countries.
targetString: Nga 23 Ogwokusatu 2020, Ekitongole ky’Ebigezo ekya Cambridge International Examinations (CIE) kyalangiririra nga kisazaamu ebigezo bya Cambridge IGCSE, Cambridge O Level, Cambridge International AS & A Level, Cambridge AICE Diploma, ne Cambridge Pre-U examinations eby’Ogwokutaanu/Ogwomukaaga 2020 mu nsi zonna.

sourceString: International Baccalaureate exams have also been cancelled.School closures impact not only students, teachers, and families, but have far-reaching economic and societal consequences.
targetString: Ebigezo bya International Baccalaureate nabyo byasazibwamu. Okuggala amasomero tekukosa bayizi bokka, na basomesa na maka naye kukosa n’ebyenfuna wamu n’ebitundu abantu mwe babeera.

sourceString: School closures in response to COVID-19 have shed light on various social and economic issues, including student debt, digital learning, food insecurity, and homelessness, as well as access to childcare, health care, housing, internet, and disability services.
targetString: Okuggala amasomero olw’okuziyiza COVID-19 kitangaazizza ebintu bingi ebikwata ku bantu n’ebyenfuna omwo nga mwe muli ebbanja eri abaana, okusomera ku kompyuta, ebyokwerinda ku byemmere, n’obutabeera na wa kubeera, wamu n’okubulwa okulabirirwa, ennyumba, yintaneeti, n’obuweereza eri abalina obulemu.

sourceString: The impact was more severe for disadvantaged children and their families, causing interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems, and consequent economic cost to families who could not work.In response to school closures, UNESCO recommended the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.
targetString: Okukosebwa kuno kubadde kwa maanyi ku baana abali mu bwetaavu wamu n’amaka mwe bava, ne kireetera okutaataagana mu byokusoma, endya embi, obuzibu mu kulabirira abaana n’amaka okukosebwa mu byensimbi naddala abo ababadde tebakola. Olw’okuggalawo kw’amasomero, UNESCO yasemba enteekateeka y’okusomera ewaka ne app okusomerwa amasomero n’abasomesa bye basobola okukozesa okutuuka ku baana wamu n’okukendeeza ku kutaataagana mu byenjigiriza.

sourceString: Efforts to stem the spread of COVID-19 through non-pharmaceutical interventions and preventive measures such as social-distancing and self-isolation have prompted the widespread closure of primary, secondary, and tertiary schooling in over 100 countries.Previous outbreaks of infectious diseases have prompted widespread school closings around the world, with varying levels of effectiveness.
targetString: Kaweefube w’okusaasaanya COVID-19 ataliimu kukozesa ddagala n’obukodyo bw’okutangira gamba nga okwewa amabanga n’okweyawula kireeseewo okuggala amasomero ga pulayimale, sekendule, n’amatendekero aga waggulu mu mawanga agasukka mu 100. Okubalukawo kw’endwadde ezisiigibwa okw’emabegako kwatanula okuggalwa kw’amasomero mu nsi yonna naye ng’ebibala ebivaamu tebifaanagana.

sourceString: Mathematical modelling has shown that transmission of an outbreak may be delayed by closing schools.
targetString: Okunoonyereza okwesigamiziddwa ku bibalo kulaze nti okusaasaana kw’obulwadde kuyinza okukendeera ng’amasomero gaggaddwawo.

sourceString: However, effectiveness depends on the contacts children maintain outside of school.
targetString: Wabula, kino okukola obulungi, kisinziira ku bantu abayizi be bakwatagana nabo ebweru w’amasomero.

sourceString: School closures may be effective when enacted promptly.
targetString: Eky’okuggalawo amasomero kisobola okukola obulungi bwe gaba nga gaggaddwawo mu budde.

sourceString: If school closures occur late relative to an outbreak, they are less effective and may not have any impact at all.
targetString: Okuggalawo kw’amasomero bwe kukolebwa ekikeerezi okusinziira ku kubalukawo kw’obulwadde, tekikola bulungi era kiyinza obutagasizaako ddala.

sourceString: Additionally, in some cases, the reopening of schools after a period of closure has resulted in increased infection rates.
targetString: Mu ngeir y’emu, mu mbeera ezimu, okuggulawo kw’amasomero oluvannyuma lw’okuggalwawo okumala ebbanga kuvuddemu okweyongera kw’obulwadde.

sourceString: As closures tend to occur concurrently with other interventions such as public gathering bans, it can be difficult to measure the specific impact of school closures.During the 1918-1919 influenza pandemic in the United States, school closures and public gathering bans were associated with lower total mortality rates.
targetString: Olw’okuba okuggalawo kutera okubeererawo olumu n’ebikolebwa ebirala okuziyiza okusaasaana kw’obulwadde gamba ng’enkuŋŋaana, kisobola okubeera ekizibu okupima okukosebwa kwennnyini okuva ku kuggala amasomero. Mu nawookeera wa ssenyiga eyaliwo mu 1918-1919 mu America, okuggalawo kw’amasomero n’okuyimiriza enkuŋŋaana byakwanyizibwa n’okufa okutono.

sourceString: Cities that implemented such interventions earlier had greater delays in reaching peak mortality rates.
targetString: Ebibuga ebyakola ku bukodyo obw’engeri eyo mu kusooka byalwawo okutuuka ku ntikko y’okufa okw’amaanyi.

sourceString: Schools closed for a median duration of 4 weeks according to a study of 43 US cities' response to the Spanish Flu.
targetString: Amasomero gaggalawo okumala ebbanga nga lya wiiki 4 okusinziira ku kunoonyereza kw’omu America okw’omu bibuga 43 nga Spanish Flu abaluseewo.

sourceString: School closures were shown to reduce morbidity from the Asian flu by 90% during the 1957–58 outbreak, and up to 50% in controlling influenza in the US, 2004–2008.Multiple countries successfully slowed the spread of infection through school closures during the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
targetString: Okuggalawo amasomero kwalagibwa nga kukendeeza ku kusiigibwa ssenyiga ayitibwa Asian flu okutuuka ku bitundu 90% mu kiseera ky’okubalukawo kw’obulwadde mu 1957–58, n’okutuuka ku bitundu 50% mu kulwanyisa ssenyiga mu Amerika, 2004–2008. Amawanga mangi gaakendeeza ku kusaasaanya obulwadde nga gayitira mu kuggala amasomero mu kiseera kya nawookeera wa ssenyiga 2009 H1N1.

sourceString: School closures in the city of Oita, Japan, were found to have successfully decreased the number of infected students at the peak of infection; however closing schools was not found to have significantly decreased the total number of infected students.
targetString: Okuggala amasomero mu kibuga kya Oita, Japan, kwazuulibwa nga kwakendeereza ddala omuwendo gw’abayizi abakwatibwa obulwadde mu kiseera we bwatumbiirira; wabula okuggala amasomero tekwazuulibwa kuba nga kwakendeeza omuwendo gw’abayizi abakwatibwa obulwadde.

sourceString: Mandatory school closures and other social distancing measures were associated with a 29% to 37% reduction in influenza transmission rates.
targetString: Okuggalawo amasomero okw’obuwaze n’enkola endala ez’okwewa amabanga zaali zeekwanya ku kigero ekiri wakati w’ebitundu 29% okutuuka ku 37% mu kukendeeza okusaasaanya ssenyiga.

sourceString: Early school closures in the United States delayed the peak of the 2009 H1N1 Flu pandemic.
targetString: Okuggalawo amasomero amangu mu America kwalwisaawo nawookeera wa 2009 H1N1 Flu okutuuka ku ntikko.

sourceString: Despite the overall success of closing schools, a study of school closures in Michigan found that "district level reactive school closures were ineffective."During the swine flu outbreak in 2009 in the UK, in an article titled "Closure of schools during an influenza pandemic" published in the Lancet Infectious Diseases, a group of epidemiologists endorsed the closure of schools in order to interrupt the course of the infection, slow further spread and buy time to research and produce a vaccine.
targetString: Wadde ng’okuggalawo amasomero kyali kya buwanguzi, okunoonyereza okukwata ku kuggalawo amasomero mu Michigan kwazuula nti "okuggalawo amasomero okwakolebwa ng’obulwadde bumaze okusaasaana tekwavaamu kalungi." Mu kiseera ky’okubalukawo kwa ssenyiga mu 2009 mu UK, mu kiwandiiko ekyafulumirako omutwe "Okuggalawo amasomero mu kiseera kya nawookeera wa ssenyiga"; ekiwandiiko ekyo kyafulumira mu Lancet Infectious Diseases, ekibinja ky’abanoonyereza ku ndwadde baasemba okuggalawo kw’amasomero nga baluubirira okutaataaganya okusaasaana kw’obulwadde n’okufuna ekiseera okunoonyereza wamu n’okukola eddagala erigema.

sourceString: Having studied previous influenza pandemics including the 1918 flu pandemic, the influenza pandemic of 1957 and the 1968 flu pandemic, they reported on the economic and workforce effect school closure would have, particularly with a large percentage of doctors and nurses being women, of whom half had children under the age of 16.
targetString: Oluvannyuma lw’okwekkaanya nawookeera wa ssenyiga eyaliwo emabegako omwo nga mwe muli n’owa 1918, nawookeera wa ssenyiga owa 1957 n’oyo owa 1968, baayogera ku kukosa okuggala amasomero kwe kulina ku byenfuna n’abakozi naddala olw’okuba nti omuwendo gw’abasawo ne bannansi abasing obungi bakyala ate ng’ekitundu kimu kyakubiri ku bo balina abaana abali wansi w’emyaka 16.

sourceString: They also looked at the dynamics of the spread of influenza in France during French school holidays and noted that cases of flu dropped when schools closed and re-emerged when they re-opened.
targetString: Baatunuulira n’engeri ssenyiga oyo gy’asaasaanamu mu Bufalansa mu kiseera ky’oluwummula lw’amasomero ga Bufalansa ne bazuula nti omuwendo gw’abalwadde ba ssenyiga gwakendeera ng’amasomero gaggaddewo ate ne guddamu okulinnya nga gagguddewo.

sourceString: They noted that when teachers in Israel went on strike during the flu season of 1999–2000, visits to doctors and the number of respiratory infections dropped by more than a fifth and more than two fifths respectively.
targetString: Baakiraba nti abasomesa mu Israel bwe beekalakaasa mu kiseera kya ssenyiga mu 1999–2000, enkyala eri abasawo n’omuwendo gw’obulwadde bw’omussizo gwakka okusukka ebitundu kimu kyakutaanu n’okusinga ku bitundu bibiri byakutaanu mu nsengeka eyo.

sourceString: For schools and childcare facilities, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.
targetString: Ku masomero n’ebifo ebirabirira abaana, Ekitongole kya U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention kisemba okuggalawo okumala ebbanga ettono olw’okusobozesa okuyonja oba okutta obuwuka bwe kiba nti waliwo omunntu omulwadde abadde mu kizimbe ky’essomero ne bwe kiba nga mu kitundu obulwadde tebunnatuuka.

sourceString: When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as cancelling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.
targetString: Bwe kiba nti waliwo okusaasaana kw’obulwadde kutono oba kusaamusaamu, obukodyo bw’okwewa amabanga busobola okukozesebwa, gamba nga okusazaamu okulambula, enkuŋŋaana, n’okusisinkana okulala okw’abantu abangi gamba ng’okukola dduyiro oba ebibiina bya kkwaya oba okuliira awamu, okwongera amabanga okuva ku buli ntebe, abayizi obutatuukiramu kumu n’obutabateera kumu, okukendeeza ku bagenyi abagenda ku ssomero, n’okukozesa woofiisi y’ebyobulamu ey’enjawulo ku baana abeeyolekerako obubonero obulinga obwa ssenyiga.

sourceString: When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.
targetString: Obulwadde bwe buba busaasaanidde ekimala mu kitundu, ng’oggyeeko obukodyo bw’okwewa amabanga, okuggalawo amasomero okumala akaseera kisaana ne kitunulwamu.

sourceString: On 26 January, China instituted measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak which included extending the Spring Festival holiday to contain the outbreak.
targetString: Nga 26 Janwali, China yayisa enkola z’okulwanyisa okubalukawo kwa COVID-19 omwali okwongezaayo ebijaguzo bya Spring Festival holiday.

sourceString: Universities and schools around the country closed.
targetString: Yunivaasite n’amasomero mu ggwanga lyonna byaggalwa.

sourceString: On 23 February, Iran's Ministry of Health announced the closure of universities, higher educational institutions and schools in several cities and provinces.
targetString: Nga 23 Ogwokubiri, Minisitule y’Ebyobulamu mu Iran yalangirira okuggalawo yunivaasite, amatendero aga waggulu n’amasomero mu bibuga ne mu bitundu ebiwerako.

sourceString: On 3 March, UNESCO released the first global numbers on school closures and affected students.
targetString: Nga 3 Ogwokusatu, UNESCO yafulumya omuwendo gw’amasomero agaggaddwa mu nsi yonna n’abayizi abakoseddwa.

sourceString: It reported that 13 countries had enacted preventive measures including the temporary closure of schools and universities, impacting 290.5 million students around the world.
targetString: Kyategeezebwa nti amawanga 13 gaali gataddewo enkola ezitangira okusaasaana kw’obulwadde omwo nga mwe muli okuggalawo amasomero ne yunivaasite okw’ekiseera, kino ne kikosa abayizi obukadde 290.5 mu nsi yonna.

sourceString: In reaction, UNESCO called on countries to support affected students and families and facilitate large-scale inclusive distance learning programmes.
targetString: Okufaananako n’ekyo, UNESCO yakubira amawanga omulanga okuwagira abayizi abakoseddwa wamu n’amaka gaabwe wamu n’okuvujjirira enteekateeka z’okusomera ewaka/ewala.

sourceString: On 4 March, the Italian government ordered the full closure of all schools and universities nationwide as Italy reached 100 deaths.
targetString: Nga 4 Ogwokusatu, gavumenti ya Italy yalangirira okuggalawo amasomero ne yunivaasite mu ggwanga lyonna kubanga Italy yali ewezezza abafu 100.

sourceString: In doing so, Italy became one of 22 countries on three continents which had announced or implemented school closures.
targetString: Bwe yakola bw’etyo, Italy n’efuuka emu ku mawanga 22 ku ssemazinga ssatu eyalangirira oba eyaggala amasomero.

sourceString: On 5 March, the majority of learners affected by COVID-19 emergency measures were located in China, with 233 million learners affected, followed by Japan at 16.5 million and Iran at 14.5 million.
targetString: Nga 5 Ogwokusatu, abayinzi abasing obungi abaakosebwa enkola z’okwewala COVID-19 ez’amangu baali mu China, ewaali abayizi obukadde 233 abaakosebwa, okwo ne kuddako Japan n’obukadde 16.5 ne Iran obukadde 14.5.

sourceString: By 10 March, one in five students worldwide was "staying away from school due to the COVID-19 crisis" while another one in four was barred from higher education institutions.
targetString: Nga 10 Ogwokusatu, omuyizi omu ku bayizi bataanu mu nsi yonna "teyali mu ssomero olw’obunkenke bwa COVID-19" so ng’ate omulala omu ku bana yali tagenda mu ttendekero erya waggulu.

sourceString: On 13 March, governments in 49 countries announced or implemented school closures, including 39 countries which closed schools nationwide and 22 countries with localised school closures.
targetString: Nga 13 Ogwokusatu, gavumenti mu mawanga 49 zaalangirira oba zaggala amasomero, omwo nga mwe muli amawanga 39 agaggala amasomero mu ggwanga lyonna ate n’amawanga 22 agaggala mu bitundu bimu na bimu.

sourceString: By 16 March, this figure increased from 49 to 73 countries according to UNESCO.
targetString: Nga 16 Ogwokusatu, omuwendo guno gweyongera okuva ku mawanga 49 okutuuka ku 73 okusinziira ku UNESCO.

sourceString: By 19 March, 50% of students worldwide were affected by school closures, corresponding to nationwide closures in 102 countries and local closures in 11 countries affecting 850 million children and youth.
targetString: Nga 19 Ogwokusatu, ebitundu 50% eby’abayizi mu nsi yonna baakosebwa okuggalwa kw’amasomero, omuwendo guno ne gukwatagana n’okuggalwa mu mawanga 102 n’okuggalwa mu bitundu bimu na bimu mu mawanga 11 era abayizi n’abavubuka obukadde 850 ne bakosebwa.

sourceString: By 20 March, over 70% of the world's learners were impacted by closures, with 124 country-wide school closures.
targetString: Nga 20 Ogwokusatu abayizi abasukka ebitundu 70% mu nsi yonna baali bakoseddwa okuggalwa kw’amasomero, ng’amasomero 124 gaggaddwa okwetooloola eggwanga.

sourceString: On 23 March, all Nigerian school were found to have been closed down by Nigerian government, markets as well as companies were closed down and children were forbidden by parents to step out of their homes.
targetString: Nga 23 Ogwokusatu, amasomero gonna ag’omu Nigeria gaasangibwa nga gaggaddwa gavumenti ya Nigeria, obutale n’amakampuni nabyo byaggalwa n’abaana bazadde baabwe baabagaana okuva ewaka.

sourceString: On 26 March, all New Zealand schools and universities have been closed down across the country.
targetString: Nga 26 Ogwokusatu, amasomero gonna ag’omu New Zealand ne yunivaasite zaggalwa okwetooloola eggwanga eryo.

sourceString: The government has imposed a two-week holiday, allowing schools to transition to forms of distant teaching as soon as possible.
targetString: Gavumenti yateekawo oluwummula lwa wiiki bbiri, kisobozese amasomero okwawula abaana ng’emu ku nkola y’okweyawula amangu ddala nga bwe kisoboka.

sourceString: Universities have closed for one week, but resumed with online teaching afterwards.
targetString: Yunivaasite zaggalwa okumala wiiki emu naye oluvannyuma ne zidda ku kusomeseza ku yintaneeti.

sourceString: Other school services remain open, but teaching is restricted to distant learning.
targetString: Obuweereza obulala obw’amasomero bwasigala butambula naye okusomesa kwakugirwa ku kusomera ku yintaneeti.

sourceString: By 27 March, nearly 90 percent of the world's student population was out of class.
targetString: Nga 27 Ogwokusatu, abayizi kumpi ebitundu by’abayizi 90 ku kikumi mu nsi yonna baali tebasoma.

sourceString: Regions with schools remaining open included Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden, and some U.S. states.
targetString: Ebitundu ebyasigaza amasomero nga maggule mwalimu Taiwan, Singapore, Australia, Sweden, n’amawanga agamu mu America.

sourceString: By 29 March, more than 1.5 billion children and other students were affected by nationwide school closures.
targetString: Nga 29 Ogwokusatu, abaana abasukka akawumbi 1.5 n’abayizi abalala baakosebwa olw’okuggala amasomero mu ggwanga lyonna.

sourceString: Others were disrupted by localized closures.
targetString: Abalala baataataaganyizibwa lwa kuggalawo mu bitundu ebimu.

sourceString: Until April 6, holidays were extended in all secondary schools of Turkmenistan.
targetString: We bwatuukira Ogwokuna nga 6, empummula zaayongezebwayo mu masomero gonna ag’e Turkmenistan.

sourceString: An order signed by the Ministry of Education as a preventative measure aims to prevent the spread of respiratory diseases in connection with the WHO coronavirus pandemic.
targetString: Ekiragiro ekyateekebwako omukono Ministule y’Ebyenjirigiza ng’engeri y’okuziyiza kiruubirira okuziyiza endwadde z’okussa nga kikolaganira wamu ne kaweefube wa WHO mu kulwanyisa coronavirus.

sourceString: 10 countries have localised schools closures, UNESCO estimates  473,933,356  learners are potentially at risk (pre-primary to upper-secondary education) and 77,938,904 learners are potentially at risk in tertiary education.
targetString: Amawanga 10 gaggala amasomero mu bitundu byago eby’enjawulo, UNESCO eteebereza nti abayizi 473,933,356 balabika nga bali mu bulabe (okuva ku nasale okutuuka ku siniya) n’abayizi 77,938,904 mu matendekero aga waggulu nabo balabika okuba mu buzibu.

sourceString: Note: Figures correspond to total number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8] who could be affected should localised closures become countrywide.
targetString: Weetegereze: Emiwendo egyo gikwatagana n’omuwendo gw’abayizi abasoma mu nasale, pulayimale, sekendule eya wansi ne sekendule eya waggulu [emitendera gya ISCED okuva ku 0 okutuka ku 3], wamu n’amatendekero aga waggulu [emitendera ISCED okuva ku 5 okutuka ku 8] abayinza okukosebwa singa okuggala amasomero kubuna eggwanga lyonna.

sourceString: Enrolment figures based on latest UNESCO Institute of Statistics data.
targetString: Emiwendo egyo egy’abayizi abali mu masomero gyesigamiziddwa ku bibalo bya UNESCO Institute of Statistics ebyakasembyeyo.

sourceString: School closures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic have shed a light on numerous issues affecting access to education, as well as broader socio-economic issues.
targetString: Okuggala amasomero olw’okulwanyisa nawookeera wa COVID-19 kwolese ensonga ez’enjawulo ezikosa ebyenjigiriza wamu n’ensonga endala ez’ebyenfuna n’embeera z’abantu.

sourceString: As of March 12, more than 370 million children and youth are not attending school because of temporary or indefinite country wide school closures mandated by governments in an attempt to slow the spread of COVID-19.
targetString: Nga 12 Ogwokusatu, abaana n’abavubuka abasukka mu bukadde 370 tebasoma olw’okuggalawo amasomero okw’ekiseera oba okutaliiko kiseera mu ggwanga mu kaweefube w’okukendeeza ku mbiro z’okusaasaana kwa COVID-19.

sourceString: As of 29 March, nearly 90% of the world's learners were impacted by closures.Even when school closures are temporary, it carries high social and economic costs.
targetString: Nga 29 Ogwokusatu, abayizi kumpi ebitundu 90% mu nsi yonna baakosebwa olw’okuggalawo. Newankubadde ng’okuggalawo kw’amasomero kwa kiseera, kukosa abantu mu mbeera eza bulijjo ne mu byenfuna.

sourceString: The disruptions they cause affect people across communities, but their impact is more severe for disadvantaged children and their families including interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems and consequent economic cost to families who cannot work.
targetString: Okutaataaganya okwo kukosa abantu mu bitundu byabwe, naye okukosebwa okwo kwa maanyi nnyo ku baana abali mu bwetaavu wamu n’amaka mwe bava omwo nga mwe muli okutaataaganya okusoma, endya embi, obuzibu mu ndabirira y’abaana n’okukosa amaka agatasobola kukola mu byenfuna.

sourceString: Working parents are more likely to miss work when schools close in order to take care of their children, incurring wage loss in many instances and negatively impacting productivity.
targetString: Abazadde abakola balabika okuba nga tebasobola kukola amasomero bwe gaggalwa kubanga baba balina okulabirira abaana baabwe, olwo ne bafiirwa emisaala mu ngeri ez’enjawulo ate n’enkola n’ekosebwa.

sourceString: Localised school closures place burdens on schools as parents and officials redirect children to schools that are open.
targetString: Okuggala amasomero mu bitundu ebimu kikaluubiriza amasomero kubanga abazadde n’aboobuyinza bakyusa abaana ne babazza mu masomero amaggule.

sourceString: Women often represent a large share of health-care workers and often cannot attend work because of childcare obligations that result from school closures.
targetString: Abakyala batera nnyo okutwala ettundutundu ly’abajjanjabi ddene era bwebatyo tebatera kukola olw’obuvunaanyizibwa bw’okulabirira abaana bwe baba balina okukola amasomero nga gaggaddwa.

sourceString: This means that many medical professionals are not at the facilities where they are most needed during a health crisis.
targetString: Kino kitegeeza nti abasawo bangi tebali mu bifo gye basinga okwetaagibwa mu kiseera kya kazigizigi mu byobulamu.

sourceString: Lack of access to technology or fast, reliable internet access can prevent students in rural areas and from disadvantaged families.
targetString: Ekizibu ky’obutaba na tekinologiya oba yintaneeti edduka, ate nga yeesigika kisobola okuziyiza abayizi mu bitundu eby’ebyalo n’abo abava mu maka ag’abaana abateesobola.

sourceString: Lack of access to technology or good internet connectivity is an obstacle to continued learning, especially for students from disadvantaged families.
targetString: Obutasobola kufuna tekinologiya oba yintaneeti ennungi muziziko gwa maanyi mu kuyiga, naddala eri abaana abava mu maka agateesobola.

sourceString: In response to school closures caused by COVID-19, UNESCO recommends the use of distance learning programmes and open educational applications and platforms that schools and teachers can use to reach learners remotely and limit the disruption of education.To aid in slowing the transmission of COVID-19, hundreds of libraries have temporarily closed.
targetString: Olw’ekizibu ky’okuggala amasomero olwa COVID-19, UNESCO esemba enteekateeka z’okusomera ewala ne app z’okusomerako amasomero n’abasomesa bye basobola okukozesa okusomesa abaana nga tebali nabo n’okukendeeza ku kutaataaganya ebyenjigiriza. Era olw’okwagala okukendeeza ku nsaasaanya ya COVID-19, ebifo ebisomerwamu ebitabo nkumu na nkumu byaggalwa.

sourceString: In the United States, numerous major cities announced public library closures, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and New York City, affecting 221 libraries.
targetString: Mu America, ebibuga ebinene ebiwerako byalangirira nti biggaddewo ebifo omusomerwa ebitabo, omuli, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, ne New York, era nga kino kyakosa ebifo 221 ebisomerwamu ebitabo.

sourceString: For students without internet at home, this increases the difficulty of keeping up with distance learning.
targetString: Eri abayizi abatalina yintaneeti waka, kino kyongera okukalubya obusobozi by’okuyigira ewala.

sourceString: School closures puts a strain on parents and guardians to provide childcare and manage distance learning while children are out of school.
targetString: Okuggala amasomero kwakaluubiriza abazadde n’abalabirira abaana okukola omulimu gw’okubalabirira ate n’okubasobozesa okwenyigira mu nteekateeka y’okusomera ewala ng’abaana tebali ku ssomero.

sourceString: In the absence of alternative options, working parents often leave children alone when schools close and this can lead to risky behaviours, including increased influence of peer pressure and substance abuse.
targetString: Olw’obubulwa bw’ekyokukola, abazadde abakola batera okuleka abaana baabwe ewaka ng’amasomero gaggaddwa, olwo bo ne bagenda okukola naye kino kibaleetera okufuna empisa embi omuli bannaabwe okubasigamu empisa embi ate n’okutandika okukozesa ebiragala.

sourceString: Many children worldwide rely on free or discounted meals at schools.
targetString: Abaana bangi mu nsi yonna beesigamye ku mmere ey’obwereere oba etagula ssente nnyingi ku ssomero.

sourceString: When schools close, nutrition is compromised.Nutrition plays a critical role in cognitive development and academic performance for children.In Washington State, around 45% of the states 1.1 million students enrolled in traditional public and charter schools qualify for subsidised school meals.
targetString: Amasomero bwe gaggalawo, n’endya ennungi esalikako. Endya ennungi ya mugaso nnyo mu nkulaakulana y’obwongo ne mu kukola kw’abayizi mu by’okuyiga. Mu Washington, ebitundu ebiwera nga 45% be bayizi nga akakadde 1.1 abali mu masomero ga gavumenti n’ag’obwannannyini baweebwa emmere ku ssente ensaamusaamu mu masomero.

sourceString: At least 520,000 students and their families may be affected by food insecurity as a result of school closures.School lunch programmes are the second-biggest anti-hunger initiative in the United States after food stamps.
targetString: Abayizi waakiri 520,000 n’amaka mwe bava bayinza okukosebwa olw’emmere entono nga kiva ku kuggalawo masomero. Enteekateeka y’ekyemisana ky’essomero ye kaweefube akwata ekifo ekyokubiri mu kulwanyisa enjala mu America.

sourceString: Every year, nearly 30 million children rely on schools to provide free or low-cost meals including breakfast, lunch, snacks, and even dinner.In Alabama, where state-wide school closures as of 18 March have affected over 720,000 students, the state Superintendent announced that staff in schools disproportionately affected by poverty would create meal distribution networks to provide food for students who rely on school lunches.
targetString: Buli mwaka, abaana kumpi ng’obukadde 30 beesigama ku masomero okufuna emmere ey’obwereere oba ey’essente entonotono omwo nga mwe muli ekyenkya, ekyemisana, obumpwakimpwaki n’ekyeggulo. Mu Alabama, okuggala amasomero gye kwakoseza abayizi abwera 720,000 olwa 18 Ogwokusatu we lwatuukira, Aboobuyinza mu kitundu ekyo baalangirira nti abakozi mu masomero abakoseddwa obwavu bajja kukola obujegere bw’okubunyisa emmere mu bayizi abeesigama ku kyemisana ky’essomero.

sourceString: School closures negatively impact student learning outcomes.
targetString: Okuggala amasomero kukosa ensoma y’abayizi.

sourceString: Schooling provides essential learning and when schools close, children and youth are deprived opportunities for growth and development.
targetString: Okugenda ku ssomero kuyamba mu kuyiga ebyamakulu era amasomero bwe gaggalawo, abaana n’abavubuka basubwa emikisa gy’okukula mu byobwongo.

sourceString: The disadvantages are disproportionate for under-privileged learners who tend to have fewer educational opportunities beyond school.Student drop-out rates tend to increase as an effect of school closures due to the challenge of ensuring all students return to school once school closures ends.
targetString: Abasinga okukosebwa beebo abateesobola abatera okubeera n’emikisa emitono egy’okusoma nga bavudde ku ssomero. Ebigero by’abayizi abava mu masomero bitera okweyongera nga kiva ku kuggala amasomero nga kiva ku kusoomooza kw’okulaba nti abayizi bonna baddayo ku ssomero ng’ekiseera ekyokugaggulawo kituuse.

sourceString: This is especially true of protracted closures.Schools are hubs of social activity and human interaction.
targetString: Okusinga ennyo kino kikola ku kuggalawo okw’ekiseera ekiwanvu ennyo. Amasomero bifo bya nkizo omukolerwa ebintu eby’enjawulo wamu n’abantu okutabaganiramu.

sourceString: When schools are closed, many children and youth miss out of on social contact that is essential to learning and development.When schools close parents are often asked to facilitate the learning of children at home and can struggle to perform this task.
targetString: Amasomero bwe gaba amaggale, abaana bangi basubwa okutabagana ne bannaabwe, okutabagana okwo kukulu nnyo mu kuyiga n’okukula kwabwe. Amasomero bwe gaggalwa, abazadde basabibwa okuyambako abaana baabwe mu byokuyiga ewaka era bakaluubirirwa okukola omulimu ogwo.

sourceString: This is especially true for parents with limited education and resources.
targetString: Kino kisinga kukaluubirira abazadde abataasoma kimala n’abatalina bya kukozesa bimala.

sourceString: Potential impacts of school closures and reliance on distance learning are not addressed in federal acts of legislation at this time.
targetString: Okukosebwa okuyinza okuva mu kuggala amasomemero n’okwesigama ku kusomera ewaka tekwogerwako mu mateeka ga gavumenti ez’ebitundu mu kiseera kino.

sourceString: Formal education — as opposed to informal education or non-formal education — tends to refer to schools, colleges, universities and training institutions.
targetString: Okusoma okutongole — bw’ogeraageranya n’okwo okutali kutongole — kutera kutegeeza masomero, kolegi oba yunivaasite oba amatendekero.

sourceString: A 1974 report by the World Bank defined formal education as the following:Formal education: the hierarchically structured, chronologically graded ‘education system’, running from primary school through the university and including, in addition to general academic studies, a variety of specialised programmes and institutions for full-time technical and professional training.The majority of data collected on the number of students and learners impacted by COVID-19 has been calculated based on the closure of formal education systems.
targetString: Alipoota ya World Bank eya 1974 yannyonnyola okusoma okutongole mu ngeri eno: Okusoma okutongole: enteekateeka y’omuyungiro gw’ebyenjigiriza etegekeddwa mu ngeri y’okuddiriŋŋana, ng’ova ku ddaala erimu n’odda ku ddaala eddala, nga kuva ku pulayimale okutuuka ku yunivaasite omwo nga mwe muli n’okusoma okw’awamu, pulagulaamu ez’enjawulo n’amatendekero ag’obutendeke obw’enjawulo n’obukugu obw’enjawulo. Obubaka obusinga okukuŋŋaanyizibwa ku muwendo gw’abayizi abakoseddwa COVID-19 gubalibwa okusinziira ku matendekero agaggaddwa.

sourceString: The UNESCO Institute for Statistics provides figures on students impacted by COVID-19 corresponding to the number of learners enrolled at pre-primary, primary, lower-secondary, and upper-secondary levels of education [ISCED levels 0 to 3], as well as at tertiary education levels [ISCED levels 5 to 8].
targetString: Ekitongole kya UNESCO Eky’Ebibalo (UNESCO Institute for Statistics) kiwa ebibalo ebikwata ku bayizi abakoseddwa COVID-19 nga gukwatagana n’omuwendo gw’abayizi abali mu nnasale, pulayimale, sekendule eya wansi, sekendule eya waggulu [emitendera ISCED 0 okutuuka ku 3], wamu n’amatendekero aga waggulu [emitendera ISCED 5 okutuuka ku 8].

sourceString: Early childhood educational programmes are usually designed for children below the age of 3 and may refer to preschools, nursery schools, kindergartens, and some day care programmes.
targetString: Enteekateeka za nnasale (Early childhood educational programmes) zitera kutegekerwa abaana abataweza myaka 3 era nga amasomero ago gasobola okwogerwako nga preschools, nursery schools, kindergartens, n’amalala googerwako ng’amasomero agalabibira abaana emisana (day care programmes).

sourceString: While many primary and secondary schools have closed around the world due to COVID-19, measures impacting early childhood educational programmes have varied.
targetString: Weewaawo amasomero ga pulayimale ne sekendule mangi mu nsi gaggaddewo olwa COVID-19, enkola ezikosezza amasomero ga nnasale za njawulo.

sourceString: In some countries and territories, preschools and day cares are considered necessary services and have not closed in tandem with broader school closure measures.In the United States, the Washington State Department of Children, Youth, and Families encouraged child care and early learning centres to stay open.
targetString: Mu mawanga agamu ne mu bitundu ebimu, nnasale n’amasomero agalabirira abaana emisana gatwalibwa ng’obuweereza obuteekwa okubaawo era go tegaggalawo lumu n’ago amalala. Mu America, Ekitongole ekikola ku nsonga z’abaana n’amaka (Washington State Department of Children, Youth, and Families) kyakubiriza ebifo ebirabirira abaana ne nnasale okusigala nga biggule.

sourceString: Some school districts may offer alternative child care options, prioritising the children of first responders and healthcare workers.
targetString: Distrikiti z’amasomero ezimu ziyinza okuteekawo enteekateeka z’okulabirira abaana ez’enjawulo nga zikulembeza abaana b’abo abadduukirira abantu wamu n’ababasawo.

sourceString: The governor of Maryland mandated that specific child care services remain open for the children of emergency personnel while Washington State and California have left it to the discretion of care providers.
targetString: Gavana wa Maryland yalagira nti wabeewo ebifo by’obuweereza bw’abaana ebisigala nga biggule okufa ku baana b’abo abadduukirira so ng’ate Washington State ne California bo baakirekera abo bennyini abakola ku kulabirira abaana okusalawo.

sourceString: California Governor Gavin Newsom explained his state's position, saying “We need our child care facilities, our daycare centers, to operate to absorb the impact of these school closures.”
targetString: Gavana wa California, Gavin Newsom yannyonnyola okusalawo kw’Ekitundu kye bwe yagamba nti, “Twetaaga obuweereza bw’abaana baffe, ebifo ebirabirirwamu abaana bikole era bituyambe mu kukosebwa kw’okuggala amasomero.”

sourceString: Colorado has encouraged the development of "tool kits" for parents to use at home to emulate the lessons children would have received in their early learning programmes.In Japan, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe closed all schools throughout the country until April 8, however, children's daycare facilities were excluded.
targetString: Ekitundu ky’e Colorado kikubiriza okukozesa “ebyokuzannyisa” ebifaananako n’ebyo abaana bye bandibadde nabyo ku ssomero mu nteekateeka yaabwe ey’okuyiga okusookerwako. Yo mu Japan, Ssaabaminisita, Shinzo Abe yaggala amasomero gonna mu ggwanga okutuusa nga 8 Ogwokuna, wabula byo ebifo ebirabirirwamu abaana tebyaggalwa.

sourceString: In early March, five adults associated with a nursing facility for preschool children in Kobe tested positive for coronavirus.
targetString: Mu Gwokusatu nga gutandika, abantu abakulu bataanu abakolera mu masomero ga nnasale mu Kobe baazuulibwa nga balina coronavirus.

sourceString: After testing over one hundred children at the facility, a preschool student was found to be carrying the virus.
targetString: Oluvannyuma lw’okukebera abaana kikumi mu kifo ekyo, omwana omu owa nnasale yazuulibwa ng’alina akawuka ako.

sourceString: Primary or elementary education typically consists of the first four to seven years of formal education.
targetString: Omutendera gwa pulayimale oba okusoma okusookerwako kutera kubeera kwa myaka okuva ku ena okutuuka ku myaka musanvu mu kusoma okutongole.

sourceString: The International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) canceled the examinations for its Diploma Programme and Career-related Programme candidates scheduled between 30 April and 22 May 2020, reportedly affecting more than 200,000 students worldwide.
targetString: Ekitongole kya International Baccalaureate Organization (IBO) kyasazaamu ebigezo bya Dipulooma n’abo Abaluubirizi b’emisomo egy’enjawulo ebyali bitegekeddwa wakati wa 30 Ogwokuna ne 22 Ogwokutaanu 2020, era nga kigambibwa nti abayizi abaakosebwa mu nsi yonna olw’enteekateeka eno baali 200,000.

sourceString: The IBO stated that it would award candidates their diplomas or certificates based on "their coursework" and "the established assessment expertise, rigor, and quality control already built into the programme."
targetString: Ekitongole kya IBO kyagamba nti kijja kuwa abaluubirizi dipulooma zaabwe oba satifikeeti okusinziira ku “mirimu” gye baakola “wamu n’obumanyirivu bw’okwekenneenya enkola y’abayizi, obukakali bw’enkola yaabwe, n’okufa ku mutindo okuli mu nteekateeka y’emisomo egyo.”

sourceString: Tertiary education, also known as higher education, refers to the non-compulsory educational levels that follow completion of secondary school or high school.
targetString: Okusoma okwa waggulu, kitegeeza okusoma okutali kwa buwaze okulimu okumaliriza sekendule oba siniya eya waggulu (haaya).

sourceString: Tertiary education is normally taken to include undergraduate and postgraduate education, as well as vocational education and training.
targetString: Okusoma okwa waggulu kutera okutwalibwa okubaamu ebyenjigiriza eby’eddaala erya wansi (undergraduate) n’erya waggulu (postgraduate), wamu n’okutendekebwa mu byemikono.

sourceString: Individuals who complete tertiary education generally receive certificates, diplomas, or academic degrees.
targetString: Abantu kinnoomu abamaliriza okusoma kw’amatendekero aga waggulu batera okufuna satifikeeti, dipulooma oba ddiguli.

sourceString: Undergraduate education is education conducted after secondary education and prior to post-graduate education, for which the learner is typically awarded a bachelor's degree.
targetString: Ddiguli esookerwako omuntu agisoma ng’amazeeko emisomo gya sekendule naye nga tannagenda ku ddiguli yaakubiri, era mu misomo egyo omuyizi mw’aweerwa ddiguli esookerwako.

sourceString: Students enrolled in higher education programmes at colleges, universities, and community colleges are often refereed to in countries such as United States as "college students."The closure of colleges and universities has widespread implications for students, faculty, administrators, and the institutions themselves.
targetString: Abayizi abeewandiisa okubakana n’emisomo egya waggulu mu kolegi, yunivaasite ne kolegi ez’omu bitundu batera okwogerwako mu mawanga ag’enjawulo nga America nga "abayizi ba kolegi." Okuggalawo kwa kolegi ne yunivaasite kwakosa nnyo abayizi, abasomesa baabwe, abakulembeze b’amatendero ago n’amatendero ago gennyini.

sourceString: Colleges and universities across the United States have been called upon to issue refunds to students for the cost of tuition and room and board.
targetString: Kolegi ne yunivaasite mu America bisabiddwa okudddiza abayizi ssente zaabwe ez’ebisale n’ebisulo bye baali bamaze okusasula.

sourceString: In the United States of America, Colleges and universities operate as "mini-cities" which generate significant revenue for cities, states, and regions.
targetString: Mu America, kolegi ne yunivaasite zikola “ng’ebibuga ebitonotono” era nga ziviiramu ddala omusolo gw’amawanga oba ebitundu mwe ziba.

sourceString: For example, Princeton University contributed $1.58 billion USD to the New Jersey economy and students spent about $60 million in off-campus spending.
targetString: Okugeza, Princeton University yawaayo akawumbi ka doola 1.58 eri New Jersey era abayizi ne basaasaanya obukadde bwa doola 60 nga tebali ku ssomero.

sourceString: College and university closures have a domino effect on economies with far-reaching implications.According to Linda Bilmes of the Harvard Kennedy School, "local hotels, restaurants, cafes, shops, car rental agencies and other local businesses obtain a significant share of annual revenue from graduation week and college reunions...
targetString: Okuggala kolegi ne yunivaasite kulina bingi bye kutuusa ku byenfuna era n’ebiva mu kino biwerera ddala. Okusinziira ku Linda Bilmes owa Harvard Kennedy School, "wooteeri z’omu bitundu, ebifo ebiriirwamu, ebitunda kaawa, amaduuka, amakampuni agapangisa emmotoka ne bizinensi endala gafuna ssente nnyini mu wiiki ebeeramu amatikkira n’okutabagabana kw’abayizi...

sourceString: these communities will suffer a lot of economic damage if the colleges remain closed at that time."Small towns which rely on college students to support the local economy and provide labour to local businesses are especially impacted by school closures and the exodus of students from campus.
targetString: abantu abo bajja kufiirwa nnyo mu byenfuna byabwe singa kolegi zisigala nga nzigale mu kiseera ekyo eky’amatikkira.” Obutawuni obutono obwesigama ku bayizi ba kolegi okufuna abakozi ku mirimu gy’omu kitundu bwe businze okukosebwa olw’okuggala kw’amasomero n’okuva kw’abayizi mu bitundu ebyo."

sourceString: In Ithaca, New York, Cornell University students spent at least $4 million a week in Tompkins county.
targetString: Mu Ithaca, New York, abayizi ba Cornell University baasaasaanya waakiri obukadde bwa doola 4 mu wiiki mu ssaza ly’e Tompkins.

sourceString: In the wake of Cornell's decision to keep students home following spring break and transition to virtual instruction, the Mayor of Ithaca called for "immediate and forceful federal action — we will see a horrific economic impact as a result of Cornell University closing."
targetString: Yunivaasite ya Cornell bwe yasalawo okusindika abaana ewaka oluvannyuma lw’oluwummula lwa Spring, n’okuseetuka okudda ku kusomera ku yintaneeti, Meeya wa Ithaca yasaba wabeewo "ekikolebwa gavumenti y’omu kitundu eky’amangu ate nga kiyamba – tugenda kulaba okukosebwa mu byenfuna kwa maanyi olw’okuggalawo kwa Cornell University."

sourceString: UNESCO is sharing 10 recommendations during this period:
targetString: UNESCO erina ebintu 10 by’esemba mu kiseera kino:

sourceString: Examine the readiness and choose the most relevant tools: Decide on the use high-technology and low-technology solutions based on the reliability of local power supplies, internet connectivity, and digital skills of teachers and students.
targetString: Okwekaliriza obweteefuteefu n’okulonda ebikozesebwa ebisinga okutuukirawo: Okusalawo ku nkozesa ya tekinologiya owa waggulu n’atali wa waggulu okusinziira ku bwesigike bw’amasannyalaze mu kitundu, yintaneeti mu kitundu, n’obumanyi bw’abayizi n’abasomesa ku bya kompyuta.

sourceString: This could range through integrated digital learning platforms, video lessons, MOOCs, to broadcasting through radios and TVs.
targetString: Kino kizingiramu okutabaganya enkola ez’enjawulo ez’okusomera ku kompyuta, amasomo aga viidiyo, MOOCs, wamu n’okuweereza ku leediyo ne ttivvi.

sourceString: Ensure inclusion of the distance learning programmes: Implement measures to ensure that students including those with disabilities or from low-income backgrounds have access to distance learning programmes, if only a limited number of them have access to digital devices.
targetString: Okukakasa nti buli omu afiibwako mu nteekateeka y’okusomera ewaka: Okukozesa enkola ezifaayo ne ku bayizi abalina obulemu oba abatali bulungi mu byenfuna nabo ne baba nga baganyulwa mu nteeekateeka z’okusomera ewaka, bwe kiba nti abatono ku bo balina ebyuma bye basobola okukozesa okusoma bwe batyo.

sourceString: Consider temporarily decentralising such devices from computer labs to families and support them with internet connectivity.
targetString: Okugezaako okuweereza ebyuma ebyo mu maka g’abayizi mu kifo ky’okubikuumira mu bisenge omubeera kompyuta era abayizi abo ne bayambibwako okuweebwa yintaneeti, naye kino kikolebwa nga kya kiseera.

sourceString: Protect data privacy and data security: Assess data security when uploading data or educational resources to web spaces, as well as when sharing them with other organisations or individuals.
targetString: Okukuuma obubaka nga bukisiddwa era n’okufaayo ku byokwerinda: Okwekaliriza ebyokwerinda ku bubaka nga buwanikibwa oba ng’ebyokuyiga biwanikibwa ku yintaneeti ne mu kiseera ky’okubigabana n’ebibiina ebirala oba abantu kinnoomu.

sourceString: Ensure that the use of applications and platforms does not violate students’ data privacy.
targetString: Okukakasa nti okukozesa app n’emikutu emirala tekikosa twekisize ku bubaka bw’abayizi.

sourceString: Prioritize solutions to address psychosocial challenges before teaching: Mobilize available tools to connect schools, parents, teachers, and students with each other.
targetString: Okussa ku mwanjo engeri y’okumulungula okusoomooza kw’ebirowoozo ng’okusomesa tekunnatandika: Okukuŋŋaanya ebikozesebwa ebiriwo okukwanaganya amasomero, abazadde, abasomesa n’abayizi.

sourceString: Create communities to ensure regular human interactions, enable social caring measures, and address possible psychosocial challenges that students may face when they are isolated.
targetString: Okutondawo ebitundu okukakasa nti waliwo okutabagana kw’abantu okutatadde, okusobozesa enkola z’okulabirira abantu n’okumulungula okusoomooza kw’ebirowoozo okuyinza okubaawo ng’abayizi baawuddwa ku bannaabwe.

sourceString: Plan the study schedule of the distance learning programmes: Organise discussions with stakeholders to examine the possible duration of school closures and decide whether the distance learning programme should focus on teaching new knowledge or enhance students’ knowledge of prior lessons.
targetString: Okuteekateeka enzirukanya y’okusomera ewaka: Okuteekateeka okukubaganya ebirowoozo n’abakwatibwako okumanya ebbanga okuggalawo amasomero lye kunaatwala era n’okusalawo oba ng’enteekateeka y’okusomera ewaka eneemalira ku kusomesa magezi mapya oba kunyweza ebyo abayizi bye baasomesebwa edda.

sourceString: Plan the schedule depending on the situation of the affected zones, level of studies, needs of students needs, and availability of parents.
targetString: Okuteekateeka entereeza okusinziira ku mbeera y’ekitundu ekikoseddwa, eddaala abayizi kwe bali, obwetaavu bw’abayizi n’okumanya oba ng’abazadde weebali oba tebaliiwo.

sourceString: Choose the appropriate learning methodologies based on the status of school closures and home-based quarantines.
targetString: Okulonda obukodyo bw’okuyiga obutuukira ku bigenda okusomesebwa ng’osinziira ku mbeera y’okuggala amasomero n’embeera ya kalantiini mu maka.

sourceString: Avoid learning methodologies that require face-to-face communication.
targetString: Okwewala obukodyo bw’okuyiga obwetaagisa okulabagana maaso ku maaso.

sourceString: Provide support to teachers and parents on the use of digital tools: Organise brief training or orientation sessions for teachers and parents as well, if monitoring and facilitation are needed.
targetString: Okuwa abasomesa n’abazadde obuwagizi ku ngeri y’okukozesa ebikozesebwa mu kusoma ku kompyuta: Okuteekateeka okutendekebwa okumpimpi oba okumanyiiza abasomesa n’abazadde ku ebyo ebigenda okukolebwa, bwe kiba nga wanaabaawo okulondoola okuneetaagisa mu nteekateeka eyo.

sourceString: Help teachers to prepare the basic settings such as solutions to the use of internet data if they are required to provide live streaming of lessons.
targetString: Okuyamba abasomesa okutegeka n’okwekakasa ebyo ebisookerwako gamba ng’engeri y’okukozesa data bwe baba nga beetaaga okuweereza amasomo obutereevu.

sourceString: Blend appropriate approaches and limit the number of applications and platforms: Blend tools or media that are available for most students, both for synchronous communication and lessons, and for asynchronous learning.
targetString: Okutabaganya enkola ezikolagana n’okukendeeza ku muwendo gwa app n’emikutu: Okutabaganya ebikozesebwa n’emikutu abayizi abasinga bye basobola okufuna, mu kuwuliziganya okw’awamu ne mu masomo gennyini wamu ne mu kuweereza obubaka obwolekera oludda olumu.

sourceString: Avoid overloading students and parents by asking them to download and test too many applications or platforms.
targetString: Okwewala okutikka abayizi n’abazadde omugugu ng’obagamba okuwanula app empitirivu oba okugenda ku mikutu egiwera.

sourceString: Develop distance learning rules and monitor students’ learning process: Define the rules with parents and students on distance learning.
targetString: Okuteekawo amateeka g’okuyigira ewaka n’okulondoola engeri abayizi gye bayigamu: Okwogera ku mateeka g’okuyigira ewaka n’abazadde n’abayizi.

sourceString: Design formative questions, tests, or exercises to monitor closely students’ learning process.
targetString: Okuteekateeka ebibuuzo ku buli ekiggwa okusomebwako, ebigezo n’okwegezaamu olw’okulondoola engeri abayizi gye bayigamu.

sourceString: Try to use tools to support submission of students’ feedback and avoid overloading parents by requesting them to scan and send students’ feedback
targetString: Gezaako okukozesa ebikozesebwa ebisobozesa abayizi okubuuza oba okuwa ebirowoozo byabwe era weewale okutikka abazadde omugugu gw’okwokya ebirowoozo byabayizi babiweereze.

sourceString: Define the duration of distance learning units based on students’ self-regulation skills: Keep a coherent timing according to the level of the students’ self-regulation and metacognitive abilities especially for livestreaming classes.
targetString: Teekawo ebbanga omuyizi ly’amala ku ssomo erimu okusinziira: Gera obudde obwenkankana okusinziira ku kigero ky’abayizi n’okwekubiriza kwabwe ng’osinziira ku busobozi bwabwe obw’obwongo naddala mu masomo agakolebwa obutereevu ku yintaneeti.

sourceString: Preferably, the unit for primary school students should not be more than 20 minutes, and no longer than 40 minutes for secondary school students.
targetString: Okusinga ennyo, essomo ly’abayizi aba pulayimale teryandisusse ddakiika 20 ate ku ba sekendule eddakiika 40.

sourceString: Create communities and enhance connection: Create communities of teachers, parents, and school managers to address sense of loneliness or helplessness, facilitate sharing of experience and discussion on coping strategies when facing learning difficulties.
targetString: Okutondawo ebibiina/ebibinja olw’okunyweza enkolagana: Okutondawo ebibiina/ebibinja by’abasomesa, abazadde n’abakulembera amasomero ebiyamba okumalawo ekiwuubaalo, okusobozesa okugabana obumanyirivu n’okuwaanyisiganya ebirowoozo ku bukodyo obuyinza okukozesebwa okuvvuunuka okusoomooza omuntu kw’ayinza okuba nakwo ng’akaluubirirwa okusoma.

sourceString: 290 million students out of school due to COVID-19: UNESCO releases first global numbers and mobilizes response,   UNESCO.
targetString: Abayizi obukadde 290 be batasoma olwa COVID-19: UNESCO yafulumya omuwendo gw’ensi yonna era n’ekuŋŋaanya ebikwata ku bantu bye bakoze.

sourceString: WHEREAS on March 4, 2020, I proclaimed a State of Emergency to exist in California as a result of the threat of COVID-19;
targetString: NEWANKUBADDE nga 4 Ogwokusatu 2020, nalangirira embeera eya kazigizigi mu California olwa nawookeera wa COVID-19;

sourceString: and WHEREAS in a short period of time, COVID-19 has rapidly spread throughout California, necessitating updated and more stringent guidance from federal, state, and local public health officials;
targetString: era NEWANKUBADDE mu kaseera katono, COVID-19 asaasaanidde California yenna, era nga kino kyetaagisa okuluŋŋamizibwa okuva mu gavumenti z’ebitundu, amawanga n’abeebyobulamu mu bitundu;

sourceString: and WHEREAS for the preservation of public health and safety throughout the entire State of California, I find it necessary for all Californians to heed the State public health directives from the Department of Public Health.
targetString: era NEWANKUBADDE olw’okukuuma ebyobulamu mu bantu wamu n’ebyokwerinda mu Ssaza lyonna erya California, ndaba nga kyetaagisa abatuuze b’omu California bonna okussa omwoyo ku biragiro by’Ekitongole ekikola ku byobulamu mu bantu (Department of Public Health).

sourceString: NOW, THEREFORE, I, GAVIN NEWSOM, Governor of the State of California, in accordance with the authority vested in me by the State Constitution and statutes of the State of California, and in particular, Government Code sections 8567, 8627, and 8665 do hereby issue the following Order to become effective immediately:
targetString: AWO NO, NOOLWEKYO, NZE, GAVIN NEWSOM, Gavana w’Essaza lya California, nga nkozesa obuyinza obwankwasibwa mu Ssemateeka w’Essaza lino wamu n’amateeka g’Essaza lya California, ate naddala obutundu 8567, 8627, ne 8665, nangirira Ekiragiro kino era kitandikirewo okukola:

sourceString: IT IS HEREBY ORDERED THAT:
targetString: NDAGIRA WANO NTI:

sourceString: 1) To preserve the public health and safety, and to ensure the healthcare delivery system is capable of serving all, and prioritizing those at the highest risk and vulnerability, all residents are directed to immediately heed the current State public health directives, which I ordered the Department of Public Health to develop for the current statewide status of COVID-19.
targetString: 1) Olw’okukuuma ebyobulamu mu bantu n’ebyokwerinda era n’olw’okukakasa nti abeebyobulamu basobola okuweereza abantu bonna, era n’olw’okukulembeza abo abali mu bulabe obw’amaanyi n’abasobola okukosebwa, bannansi bonna balagirwa wano nti bagondere ebiragiro by’Essaza eby’ebyobulamu, bye nagamba Abeekitongole ky’Ebyobulamu okuteekateeka olw’embeera ya COVID-19.

sourceString: Those directives are consistent with the March 19, 2020, Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response, found at: https://covid19.ca.gov/.
targetString: Ebiragiro ebyo bikwatagana bulungi n’ebyo ebya nga 19 Ogwokusatu 2020, Obubaka ku Kunokolayo Abakozi abasinga okwetaagisa mu Kiseera kya COVID-19 (Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response), ebiri ku mukutu: https://covid19.ca.gov/.

sourceString: ORDER OF THE STATE PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICER
targetString: EKIRAGIRO KYA OMUKUNGU W’EBYOBULAMU MU SSAZA

sourceString: To protect public health, I as State Public Health Officer and Director of the California Department of Public Health order all individuals living in the State of California to stay home or at their place of residence except as needed to maintain continuity of operations of the federal critical infrastructure sectors, as outlined at https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.
targetString: Olw’okukuuma obulamu bw’abatumu, nze ng’Omukungu era Ssenkulu w’Ebyobulamu mu Ssaza lya California, ndagira abantu bonna ababeera mu Ssaza lya California okubeera ewaka oba gye basula okuggyako nga bayitiddwa okugenda okuddukanya emirimu egitalina kuyimirira nga bwe kiragibwa ku mutuku https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.

sourceString: In addition, and in consultation with the Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services, I may designate additional sectors as critical in order to protect the health and well-being of all Californians.
targetString: Mu ngeri y’emu, ate era ne mu kwebuuza ku Gavana w’Obuweereza Obwamangu (Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services), nnyinza okunokolayo ebitongole ebirala ng’ebyetaagisa mu mbeera eno olw’okukuuma obulamu n’obulungi bw’abantu b’omu California bonna.

sourceString: Pursuant to the authority under the Health and Safety Code 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 and 120150, this order is to go into effect immediately and shall stay in effect until further notice.
targetString: Nga nsinziira ku buyinza obuli mu Tteeka ly’Ebyobulamu n’Okwerinda (Health and Safety Code) 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 ne 120150, ekiragiro kino kirina okussibwa mu nkola amangu ddala era kirina okugobererwa okutuusa nga waliwo ekikyusiddwamu gye bujja.

sourceString: The federal government has identified 16 critical infrastructure sectors whose assets, systems, and networks, whether physical or virtual, are considered so vital to the United States that their incapacitation or destruction would have a debilitating effect on security, economic security, public health or safety, or any combination thereof.
targetString: Gavumenti enokoddeyo ebitongole 16 eby’omugaso ennyo ng’ebyobugagga byabwe, emiyungiro, n’obukolaganyi, si nsonga oba birabwako oba bya ku yintaneeti bitwalibwa nga bya mugaso nnyo mu America era nga singa biggyibwamu amaanyi oba byonoonebwa kiyinza okuzaala embeteza ku byokwerinda, mu byenfuna, ne mu byobulamu mu bantu oba mu bisaawe ebyo byonna.
